job_title: Information Technology Support in State College, PA
pros:
Job:
Fast paced work environment. 
Easy to learn. 
Opportunity to learn more than you ever wanted to know about how Penn State does business. 
Basically retail for the IT world. If this appeals to you, you will excel here. 
Good benefits options; fairly high vacation and sick leave comparatively speaking. Good healthcare and retirement benefits. 

Area: 
Quiet surrounding area; don't live in town or near students. 
Plenty of bar and grills and good eateries in general. 
LOTS of exploration opportunities; miles and miles of hiking trails in and around the area.
cons:
Job:
Relatively low pay compared to the rest of the industry. 
Ever growing list of services and systems you will support. 
They WILL change your job description without increase in pay or title. 
Management can play favorites, assuming they stick around long enough to form a relationship. 
High turn over in the support staff. 

Area: 
In the middle of nowhere red-neck PA if you're from the city. 
The University is fairly liberal, but the rest of the area is not. (Either a pro or a con.)
Almost as or more expensive than some large cities because renters know residents will pay for it, or parents of students will pay it. 
A lot of the apartments in town are a little run down because of students. 
Houses out of town can be hit or miss in quality to price.

review_title: Huge bureaucracy, stifling at times, lots of opportunities to do your thing.
job_title: IT Manager III in University Park, PA
pros: In many respects it is an open environment where you have some freedom to try new things, and experiment. As a university there is a culture that values deliberation, so if you can make your case you might have a shot at getting to implement a new way of doing things. In my experience there hasn't been a whole lot of micromanagement or harsh treatment of employees, and deadlines are generally aspirational instead of firm. That sort of treatment varies from department to department, though.
cons: Starved for resources, both people-wise and money-wise. There is more work to be done than is possible to accomplish, and leadership often fails to set priorities that let lower-level staff know what should be left behind. The pay is abysmal compared to industry, but this is technically the non-profit sector so that is to be expected. Compared to other public universities, salaries are pretty good. Unless you are a 18-25 and single, State College is kind of a crappy place to live, and the cost of living is outrageous compared to other communities 20 miles away.

job_title: Assistant Professor in University Park, PA
pros:
Happy students, loyal alumni, beautiful campus. Many resources are available for the teaching aspects of the job. If you put your mind to it, you can become an excellent teacher. The role of research, and how well it's supported depends on which college you are in. Some have excellent support, others are in the business of pushing undergrads through the system. 

Faculty are paid quite well especially considering the low cost of living.  You can have a nice, peaceful life here...good place to raise a family.  If you're in the right department, life can be pretty good.
cons:
It's a heavily bureaucratic, compliance-oriented and dean-centric culture. Faculty governance is minimal. You'll spend more time filling out paperwork to university risk management than actually doing your work.  It's also an old boys club with respect to decision making. 

Faculty quality of life varies greatly depending on departments. Mixed messages are given about the importance of research vs. teaching. There's pressure on all sides to do more with less. Classrooms are packed to the brim with pressure for greater enrollment. 

There are great people who work here but also plenty of duds. The most depressing are the  disenfranchised faculty who stay here because the area is very family friendly and/or PSU generously gave golden handcuffs when they tried to leave.

job_title: Programmer/Analyst III in University Park, PA
pros:
Work/life balance is good
Flexibility for attending classes is a definite plus.
Tuition discount, while not as good as other universities, helps tremendously in grad school.
Once you are part of the system, it is easier to move around the university... into different roles.
cons:
Directors/Assistant directors not given adequate training on "how to be a boss".

Complaints of gender discrimination fall on deaf ears. Was told "Oh they're just guys, you have do do it for them." That is just how men are was not the answer I was looking for.

While friendly, not inclusive.

Roles are not clearly defined which is good, and bad, depending on the situation and the director.

Impossible to find another job in the university in areas that your director or assistant director is actively involved in. This is because they are asked to be on all of the interview committees, even if it is not their department. You can potentially be blocked if they don't want to lose you.

review_title: A very typical graduate school in the USA
job_title: Teaching Assistant in University Park, PA
pros:
Some departments (like gravity institute and materials/nanoscience) have world-class credentials, and therefore you will too if you finish your degree there.
University's emphasis on bottom line means you need never shortchange your research by taking the extra time to teach a subject competently (don't worry, your students would rather be somewhere else as well).
Unless you deliberately live far from campus, everything is within walking distance of everything else, or at most you'll have a 20-minute bus commute in the morning.
cons:
Godawful insurance benefits (foreign nationals can't even get those, and must purchase their own unsubsidized plan in order to be hired).
75-100 hour weeks during crunches, which last between 1 week and 1 year.
Located in a midwestern college town: if you are single, there's not much to do, and if you have a family, you'll be afraid to take them more than a block from home.

job_title: Assistant Research Professor in State College, PA
pros: Generally flexible, but it depends on your area.  You are surrounded by many successful people and there are a lot of resources to help you succeed.
cons:
There are many cons to being a researcher, especially when your main objective is to receive grants and conduct high-quality research.  However, I do not think any of these are specific to Penn State.  If anything, Penn State does a very good job of making it as easy as possible.  

Staff are sometimes treated like they are 60+ hour week employees.  Staff are staff... they show up and do their work, then go home and leave work at work.  Many staff are underpaid and there is hardly any oversight from the administration on how staff are treated.  Most of the time, they are treated very well.  But, I have seen a lot of staff that are essentially worked until they can't anymore.

review_title: Faculty are treated like Royalty, Staff treated like dirt! TOXIC work environment for Staff
job_title: Administrative Support Coordinator in University Park, PA
pros:
Excellent University! Programs and opportunities for students are top notch.
University Park Campus is beautiful!  Low crime, low traffic small town, easy to get around, lots of things to do during school year. Football!
cons: Highly toxic environment for staff. Management is corrupt, and will do anything to protect bureaucracy.  Staff are treated like dirt. Management doesn't care about fairness, or keeping employees happy and healthy. No Work-Life balance for staff, only for faculty.  Management abuses their power because they know that staff have no choice but to stay at Penn State (largest employer in town). Nepotism everywhere! Managers usually hire their friends, whether or not they're qualified for the position. Staff are penalized for expressing their opinions, even if it's in a respectful manner. If you don't agree with management, they threaten to fire  you, or make your life unbearable so you'll quit.  Diversity at Penn State is a scam, all a dog & pony show. Management is racist, and does not care at all about diversity students or staff. Most positions at the top are white males, white females. Staff pay is miserable, no raises either!

job_title: Med Student in Hershey, PA
pros: they try but not hard enough
cons: harassment. negligence. mistreatment. mean staff and residents.

review_title: Lecturer (Full Time) - Pitiful Pay and Disrespectful Administration
job_title: Lecturer in State College, PA
pros: Penn State students are smart and friendly - a real pleasure to teach.
cons: Lowest pay of all state universities for lecturer of composition/rhetoric - in most cases by far.  Large class size (24 per class for freshman writing) with a 3:4 load.  Exceptionally heavy grading load (96 students per semester, required to grade multiple papers, projects, and constant other homework weekly), huge pressure by department not to give any student over a "C," and of course resentment from students about imposed standards.  Those running the program are condescending and hostile.  The morale among the large lecturer faculty (full and part time) is stunningly poor.  Can't think of a worse Writing Program (have experience with several) than this one to work in.

review_title: Great if you're full time, horrible if part time.
job_title: Library Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: Working with the students is great and very satisfying, you really feel like you are making a difference to them by working here.  There are a lot of varied job opportunities for faculty and staff.
cons: As a part time worker, they love to claim advancement from within is common but I've found that if you want a full time job here you're much better off being from outside because they never promote from within.  Leadership, especially managerial and supervisory level is poor at best and there's a culture that encourages no change from within.  There is very definite discrimination against the part time people.  There are no benefits at all for the part time workers, not even a discount for classes which I've never experienced at a college before.

job_title: Grad Assistant in State College, PA
pros:
I can't comment on all the departments as apparently grad. student employments differs greatly by department. 
If you can get a research assistantship you will be working with interesting thinkers and learning a great deal. If you realize you are not moving to a big city and don't expect big city living, the State College is an affordable town with a good deal interesting people living here.
cons: In the college of ed, there are no guarantees of funding at even a minimum level and there is even less a culture of transparency which makes it very difficult to determine who gets funding and why. Another example of failed transparency is the health care debacle which exemplifies PSU cavalier attitude towards grad students. This leads to much insecurity and apprehension as funding renewal season roles around. Little funding and many grad students lead to many avoidable issues.

review_title: Gained invaluable research experience with a top-notch research professional and mentor
job_title: Research Assistant in Reading, PA
pros: I worked with Brenda L. Russell, PhD as her research assistant for one semester, until the funding ran out. She is a top-rate researcher and highly professional. I worked telecommute (an undeniable benefit) and part-time, and Penn Sate-Berks had no qualms with this arrangement. It was one of the best experiences of my life working at PSU with Brenda. (Thereafter, I went on to work with her in copy editing a couple scholarly articles and a textbook.) Brenda possessed patience, tenacity, and opportunities to learn new skills. Being a research assistant fresh off from graduating is a great opportunity, especially if you're eager to develop research skills for grad school (SPSS, for one), or as an important skill set for a job after undergrad.
cons: I have to put a con, so... The pay was within the funding budget, so it was meager; but I didn't care about that, because I was learning so much.

job_title: in State College, PA
pros: Great vacation and sick time, 75% off education for your family, typical health benefits, as well as some other benefits around the University (half off your football donation, ability to be a member at the campus gym, etc). This is the first place I have worked where people stroll in at 8:30am and leave promptly at 5:00pm.
cons: Horrible pay for support staff unless you have worked there for 15+ years then you are drastically overpaid. Employees are set in their ways and refuse to change. The inefficiencies of the University are so blatant and have to be a huge waste of time and money. You have to look out for your own career and pay because no one else will. There are no internal promotions, you must apply to a job with outside candidates.

job_title: Director of Development in University Park, PA
pros: Competitive (though not industry-leading) compensation, continuing education, relatively easy logistics...it's nice being in a quaint college town.
cons: University is not responsive to or in any way responsible to its employees, especially physical plant workers and grad students -- seems to take the position that as the only game in town, the workers have no alternatives.  HR Transformation doesn't seem to have made HR any more effective -- but it has made it much harder to identify and reach an HR rep. Standards are high, but inconsistently so, and there are employees there who have been underperforming or acting badly towards their colleagues for decades, and yet allowed to continue working there.  The organization is not diverse or especially aware of its lack of diversity. Work-life balance can be poor, because there is no comp time -- but there's a lot of PTO available.   Finally, it's getting increasingly harder to defend the institution's ethics, in light of their odd handling of the recent fraternity scandals.

job_title: Athletic Department in Monaca, PA
pros: The campus size allows for max utilization of time and resources because it smaller and concentrated size.  Allows the choices for four year degrees or entree programs into majors at different locations. There are several clubs, organizations, varsity athletic programs. The New Wellness Center has created a great energy to the Athletic Department, and can expect a increase of enrollment because additions.
cons: A few cons of the school are the schools appropriated funds for each program, and the limited number of offered majors. There is accessibility to funds and as well as 5 majors but you get what you pay for. Beaver is limited in resources the great thing with this is your still apart of the Penn State community and can outsource for anything not at hand.

review_title: Flexibility, upward mobility, and impeccable organization
job_title: Lab Consultant in State College, PA
pros:
- The management at ITS understand that you're a college student. Inform them long in advance of an exam conflict or next-day assignment, and they'll be happy to let you off. 
- Getting promoted in Lab Consulting is always an option, if you want the extra commitment. A promotion really is a promotion, too; you become closer to the managers, and begin earning an extremely respectable hourly rate (for a college student).
- The organization is held together via their Drupal site. Nearly everything is done through the website, and it keeps everything moving super smoothly.
cons: - The management and supervisors can seem to take themselves too seriously. ITS manages the computer labs on campus, but often times it feels like being part of a military organization. For some, this might be bad. I didn't mind it so much.

review_title: Low pay in exchange for lots of freedom
job_title: Assistant Teaching PRofessor in State College, PA
pros:
- They're *trying* to be proactive about climate and diversity.
 - For the most part the people you work with are good at what they do and humble
 - Lots of time on campus in between classes and office hours to work on your own research or skills
 - Upper-level classes are very refreshing to teach 
- Work-life balance is great
- Good benefits
cons:
- Low pay --- this is academia
 - To make even a small change to a department, course, or policy, you have to go through a bunch of people whose jobs' seem to be saying "no".
 - Low-level classes will make you want to slam your head against the wall.

review_title: Perhaps the best employer in State College, but it's not as scary as you think outside higher ed/Happy Valley
job_title: Business Process Analyst in State College, PA
pros:
Alumni community love for Penn State makes you feel like you're part of something important
Excellent benefits compared to most employers outside tech
Access to a 457b
Discounted tuition
Stability - they almost never get rid of anyone (even fixed term, excellent possibility of renewal means almost certain renewal)
cons:
Decentralized decision making
Low salary for tech employees
Inconsistent compensation plans
No strategy for attracting and retaining tech talent
Dead weight - they almost never get rid of anyone

job_title: Systems Administrator III in University Park, PA
pros: Working on a college campus is great. State College and Happy Valley are great places to live. The benefits are very good, especially the state pension and the vacation time.
cons:
Salaries are much lower than in other areas as there is no other competition for IT staff in central PA. Advancement options in IT are limited once you reach a certain level. From there, one of the few options is management. There are a lot of them. Unfortunately, a high percentage of managers seem to get forced out or fired, making it a risky proposition.

IT has been going through various reorganizations for the past 10 years. IT departments are understaffed. Morale at many IT units is very low. The ultimate vision management has looks good but will the leadership team be around long enough to see it through? Or will another management team come in with yet another plan?

review_title: Penn State - A Wonderful Place to Work
job_title: Coordinator in University Park, PA
pros: Penn State is a large University with a personal touch. The intellectual capital  and diverse population of the community help create a collaborative, challenging and dynamic work environment. Compared to other higher education institutions at which I have worked (3 others), Penn State is hands down the best employer in terms of internal communication; training, growth and development of employees; and the sense of pride and community instilled in those who work there.
cons: Similar to many higher education institutions reward in a non-profit enterprise is based on an across the board salary increase each year, with a small amount of funding available for merit rewards for staff. So, if you work very very hard you are rewarded with a moderately high raise and if you work very, very little you are rewarded with a moderately low raise. Also, it is often bureaucratic and difficult to manage problem employees.

job_title: Early Childhood Teacher in Erie, PA
pros: The only pro is our amazing families and children.
cons: Low Wages, Expensive Benefits, TWO YEARS Before Benefits Kick In, Management

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: good research environment, highly collaborative work, great opportunities, good funding, nice town, low cost of living, prestigious degree, huge alumni network, some companies only look here for those in the STEM fields, top research professors.
cons: Stipend for students is significantly lower compared to other Big Ten schools.  HR is not there to protect you, it is there to protect the university - before and after the Sandusky scandal.  I had many female friends who had issues with stalking, sexual assault, rape, rape threats, etc and the department and school took action against or threatened the victims with expulsion, etc.   There are good people there in the staff and faculty working to remedy this but they are outweighed by those in power who put the university first.  There is a large lack of cultural diversity awareness among most students and staff.

review_title: Overall good, but bad management made it unbearable
job_title: Educational Program Associate in Middletown, PA
pros: Great benefits. Generous paid time off for both vacation and sick. Wonderful tuition reimbursement. Get a degree while you are there. Everything you need on a college campus is there, good food service, excellent library, and fully stocked student union with racquetball, pool, and other work out options.  Friendly and helpful co-workers. Your happiness really depends on your direct manage.r
cons: Upper management is stuck in the "We are Penn State" mentality. Not willing to look at the new changing face of higher education.  Can be very hierarchical and the bureaucracy is nearly crippling innovation. Pay is below average for other similar places. Nearly impossible to move up in the organization.

review_title: Great place to work for students.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in University Park, PA
pros:
Working part time at Penn State as a student is a wonderful experience. Managers/higher ups are totally flexible with your weekly course schedule and are always understanding during midterms/finals/other exams. 

While I cannot speak specifically to the department I work in given its small size, the challenges I'm presented with are interesting and require thought to solve. The work I'm doing now is directly translatable to my major choice.
cons:
The largest downside is there has been a great deal of restructuring of the department I work in over the last 12 months. The transition from one division to another division of the university has been completed though, so this coming semester should not have nearly as many meetings as the previous did.

I definitely would not work here after college ended though. There simply is not enough room for career development in my field here.

review_title: Being a graduate student researcher has its ups and downs.
job_title: Graduate Assistant in State College, PA
pros: It's great to be surrounded by some of the best and brightest people in the world, and research is almost never boring.  My adviser as well as majority of the faculty and staff are very competent people.  Additionally, I enjoy the company of my labmates for the most part, and when time permits, the State College social scene (be it restaurants, bars/clubs, or other entertainment) is decent.
cons: Research can easily take over your life.  As a result, it's a struggle to find a good work/life balance.  Sometimes equipment breaks, things get misplaced or misused, or the lab might be dirty from the person before you.  Additionally, a lot of the actual work culture (as a grad student) is dictated almost entirely by your adviser and/or labmates...  This can be good or bad, but it's something to consider.

review_title: A great place to work, but less so for women and people of color
job_title: Director in State College, PA
pros: Penn State, like many universities, is family friendly in my experience and a university is a great place to work since there are so many learning opportunities. And there are many, many great people.
cons: I know of too many instances of structural discrimination against women (in pay for instance) and differential treatment of people of color.  Moreover, while the work environment is friendly, it is also one that lacks accountability and people willing to speak up---or being invited to speak up.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Erie, PA
pros: Professors make or break the experience and luckily there exist a number of professors who can make the learning experience occur under any circumstance as they often are due to poor budget management.
cons: Poor budget management, new facilities, and equipment are being given to other fields that don't even use them such as spending tens of thousands of dollars on a ticker no one cares about. The engineering department is using decade-old equipment and relies on the creativity of professors to work extra hard to provide a learning experince. A certain professor was so bad, I had to question if he was even human, forunately, I heard he was fired.

review_title: Varies by department, but phenomenal experience for me.
job_title: Programmer in State College, PA
pros:
12 hours paid vacation every month, plus 8 hours sick leave.
Great benefits.
Actually believes in the concept of professional development  - people in my office are always taking time off for training seminars and software user group meetings.
Since PSU is an educational institution, you know that you're working towards something positive
Generally laid back (people in my department wear shorts and t-shirts to work)
cons:
Since it's an academic environment, there are definitely office politics.
Management styles vary - Employees in my department love their jobs, but some of them were hired from other departments where they were miserable.
Living in a college town can be very, very exhausting

review_title: Good Educational Opportunity for Graduate Students
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros:
-Departments tend to be supportive of students: professionally, financially, and outside the classroom
-A number of extracurricular activities and groups make for a more complete and positive educational experience
cons:
-Some tenured faculty are not good about obtaining enough research grant money to support their students
-Some faculty seek to use grad students as cheap labor, keeping them years after when they should have graduated
-The university's increasing emphasis on diversity is interfering with creating a climate where one's colleagues are competent and good at what they do
-Grad students are being instructed to "dumb down" coursework in order to increase enrolment in various department classes

job_title: Retired in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Size and variety of the organization.  Mission and goals are a strong drawing card.    Because of the size, there are some very interesting environments and dynamics that can create really valuable and  worthwhile learning for staff and administrators.  There are a lot of bright people to learn from and create new intiatives.
cons: Leadership was not dynamic.  Poor decision making processes.  Top down communication.  Data and information were disregarded.  Good and bright people were too often ignored.  The success of the institution often created a sense of complacency.  Resources were often not marshalled to appropriately meet problems and create solutions.  Decision makers often did not have the expertise to understand or confront organizational uncertainty or a crisis.  Personalities were often more important than knowledge and expertise.

job_title: Staff Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: The benefit package used to be above market but has slowly lost it's luster.  It is almost impossible to be fired.
cons: Salary increases based on factors unrelated to performance, such as personal relationships with supervisors. University policies are not followed by upper management and violating eithics and forcing employees to break the rules or be labeled as a trouble-maker when you speak up about violations. Job classifications are based on what pay is available in the budget, not what the employee actually does.  Too often supervisors push their work off subordinates.  Definately a place where poorly functioning employees are promoted to levels where they do not perform well; no capability to do the job or interest in self-improvement. The HR office's professional development courses do match their descriptions and are a waste of time and money for departments.  Unfortunately your performance review is also based on how many of these wasteful courses an employee takes each year.

review_title: Innovation is just a buzz word
job_title: Multimedia Specialist in University Park, PA
pros:
- Great Benefits
- Somewhat flexible work schedule
- Lots of time off
- The people who actually produce work are wonderful
cons:
- Outreach
- Salary Compensation
- Organizational Hierarchy 
- Upper Management 
    - They talk a lot of talk and little to no action
    - "Innovation" is a word they throw around all of the time but there simply isn't any
    - Upper Management are ALWAYS in meetings and almost NEVER in the office. Waste of   
      time and money for everyone.
- There is so much waste everywhere; time, money, and skills
- No way to advance

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: Some flexibility in work hours, able to work on cutting-edge research, VERY close contact to industry partners which makes future jobs easier to find. The insurance program is very good, as PSU subsidizes 80% of my insurance and 70% of dependents, but even then the premiums can get expensive.
cons: At least 3 hours from a big city, small town feel can get old after a while, cost of living is higher than expected for similar B1G schools. Grad students ultimately don't have any say in how things are done or how policies affect them.

job_title: English Lecturer in University Park, PA
pros: The only thing I like about this job is that I can set my teaching schedule, for the most part. The extended break(s) for holidays is an excellent perk to the job as well.
cons: There is way too much grading that has to be done. I don't have "free time" for friends, family, or any sort of life if I want to get grades back in a timely manner. I teach three to four classes a semester, which, if following syllabus/course material guidelines is at LEAST 3,000 pages of reading each 15 weeks, on top of emails, professional requirements, office hours, and prep. I am completely burnt out after a year and a half, and I am frankly not getting paid enough for it. I also feel like there's really no camaraderie. You are almost 100% on your own, which may work for some people, but it just doesn't for me.

review_title: It's the service industry, so don't expect much.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in State College, PA
pros:
-Flexible work hours.
-Friendly employees.
-Beats working as a banquet server, I've heard things about working as a banquet server there and none of them are positive.
cons:
-Very boring and long work, nearing the end I have to physically and mentally prepare myself for the boredom, however it is more because of the nature of the job itself, but I'm just glad I don't have to work there anymore.
-When I worked there, I keep getting this hunch that my manager secretly disliked me but had to pretend to be nice for the sake of professionalism, now if you know what I mean then you'll also know that such hunches aren't far from the truth. I heard all departments gossip a lot and I don't even want to think about what they say about me.
-Management can appear indecisive and sometimes unwilling to directly deal with issues.

review_title: Great employer for family oriented individuals.
job_title: Systems Design Specialist in University Park, PA
pros: The quality of life that you gain working here is the main reason to stay.  It is fantastic to get to see your family.  There is encouragement for exploring new ideas that are not necessarily immediately relevant to daily duties.  The University makes an effort to allow its employees to manage their own time as professionals.  There is a great financial discount for continuing one's own education.
cons: There is a disparity between genders in many positions.  Salaries are definitely below industry averages for non-educational institutions.  It is quite difficult to navigate the political landscape to effect substantive changes in the day to day operations of the University.

review_title: Great University, and it's making a LOT of money
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Harrisburg, PA
pros: Great to work with students, up to date technology and resources. Professional faculty (mostly), excellent location, part of a large, well-known university.
cons: The Staff has an incredible amount of responsibility but constantly reminded they are "staff" and not faculty.  The students would not be admitted, scheduled or graduated without the staff.  Faculty are compensated quite well (plus additional summer contracts, too) while the staff is expected to be thrilled with 1.5% raises and salaries in the mid 30's to very low 40's.

review_title: Penn State - a nice place to go to grad school! IF you have a good advisor
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in State College, PA
pros: Good financial support if you make your milestones, health benefits, nice town, beautiful area of the state, access to a lot of expertise. I had an excellent advisor.
cons: Hard to get to if you live out of state. Many poor quality advisors (a system-wide issue due to pressure on faculty to do too much, but still). It's not very diverse.

review_title: Not bad, but could be better.
job_title: Assistant Research Engineer (ARL) in State College, PA
pros: Good Benefits Package.  Lots of vacation time.  Lots of sick time.  Lots of paid holidays.  All together you get about 10 weeks off per year.  You don't work overtime.  Health benefits and retirement plans are also good.  Cost of living in the area is low.  It's really a small town, but there are a good amount of things to do because of the university.  If you like to watch college sports, this is a very good place.
cons: Pay is less than it would be elsewhere.  It's a small town and doesn't have the attractions of a major city.  Although you are relatively close to some major cities, there is really nothing within 3 hours of you.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: Working as a GRA at Penn State is very dependent on your boss in the day-to-day stuff but in general the Food Science Department is very supportive of all students and it feels like they really want you to succeed.  There are a lot of great resources available for you whether its specialized equipment you want to use or leaders in the field that you want to talk to. Also, the graduate health insurance at PSU is exceptional!
cons: Working at a Research One university can be tough on graduate students because the expectations are high. I think its pretty typical that graduate students are expected to work hard but especially at a university with this type of exposure, a lot of the faculty members expect a lot of work. As with the day-to-day expectations, it mostly depends on your boss how hours, scheduling, and office culture are handled.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in University Park, PA
pros: Generous vacation and sick time, great health insurance, time off during some University breaks, discounts to local attractions and public transport. Decent pay.
cons: Bureaucracy, bureaucracy, bureaucracy. I work for the university libraries, and I had to jump through about a thousand hoops -- including three different background checks, one of which required me to go OUT OF STATE to get it done in time to start my job in a reasonable period of time -- to actually get on-boarded, only to be told in my first meeting with HR that those checks weren't really mandatory. The employee goal-setting program is inane, overly complicated, and a waste of time.

review_title: PSU Consultant good for current students
job_title: Computer Lab Consultant in Reading, PA
pros: Great place to work during school.  Pay is decent, easy to pick up more hours.  Good way of learning more about technology.  It is also a great job to put on a resume.  Great for people with little experience.  The position is also pretty laid back and low stress.  It is also a great way to interact with other students and help them with computer problems.
cons: They want you to work too many hours during school.  This can hurt your studies and extra curricular activities.  There are no benefits since you are a part time employee.  Training is poor.  Many things that people may not be able to do when first coming on board.  Another bad thing is the people you work with are not that smart.

job_title: Administrative Support Assistant in State College, PA
pros: I was able to acquire more responsibilities that related to my skills; I was not limited to what the last person in my position was capable of. My coworkers were friendly and I looked forward to seeing them every day. I had my own office and a good benefits package. Penn State contributed to my retirement fund while I was there, and I was able to keep my fund after leaving.
cons:
The school is so huge, sometimes it feels like you don't make a difference. But if you get involved on committees it helps.
This isn't about my job in particular, but about the town:
It gets so cold in State College, and there are of course college students everywhere. Not a great town for cuisine, but there are some good finds.

review_title: Penn State University Applied Research Lab (ARL)
job_title: Undergraduate Researcher in University Park, PA
pros: Extremely smart and talented staff, abundant opportunity to work on different projects, ability to move around departments easily, laid back approach to R&D while still meeting or exceeding project goals, not overbearing or "over your shoulder" with supervision of your projects
cons: Feels like you're on your own once you're hired, have to learn the ins and outs of the lab by seeking somebody out to ask them, lots of bureaucracy since you're dealing with public and university money and contracts from clients

job_title: Anonymous Employee in University Park, PA
pros: The professors are generally kind and brilliant. If you can justify it, the money is there for just about anything. And being around students all the time can help one retain a sense of youth, well into your middle years.
cons: There is SO much red tape, and there's an elitism based on your degree beyond any non-academic position. Also, the reluctance to terminate an employee leads to many staff members doing the bare minimum.

job_title: Graduate Research and Teaching Assistant in University Park, PA
pros:
The faculty are passionate masters of their area of study, but also have realistic expectations for their grad students.

Most of the undergraduate students are highly motivated and looking to learn.

If you have difficulty with public speaking (like I did), then teaching engineers is the best practice because they'll let you know when you make a mistake, but will still be very polite and considerate.

You can expect equally challenging and rewarding experiences.
cons: Long hours, but if you're like me (and most engineering grad students) this could easily be a pro; if you love your work.

review_title: There are good areas for staff to work but not all!
job_title: Prefer Not To Say in State College, PA
pros: Time off and access to extra activities.
cons: One person can ruin you. I was bullied by other staff, physically assaulted by a employee, watched another employee get drunk at an event, students get drunk at department events, etc and because I tried to speak up I was labeled a trouble maker and excluded. I was told that I couldn’t got to HR. I was suicidal during my employment and my boss knew and wasn’t even concerned.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: Faculty are very open to working with students, there is much collaboration, and while there is some competition among graduate students, it is not cut-throat like other universities. Students are always willing to help each other out and work together on projects and assignments.
cons: Like any graduate program, the pay is not very high, but when all the benefits are considered it is more than fair. Some faculty members can be very demanding, while others are more flexible, it is important to find someone who is the right fit. Class options can be very limited some semesters.

review_title: Employer of choice in the middle of nowhere
job_title: IT Manager in State College, PA
pros: Within the IT realm, there is a serious emphasis on leadership development and lots of opportunities for professional development. There is a mentoring network, and a peer coaching network. As a research-1 university, this is a chance to play with the big boys in higher ed IT. Recent changes in IT leadership have been for the positive.
cons: It's in the middle of freaking nowhere. If you don't live for beer and football, it's not a great place to live. Also, there is a strong anti-Microsoft bent, so a lot of enterprise systems (data warehouse, e-mail, web services) run on awkward technology stacks.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: The university has great technical facilities and opportunities for experience in research, knowledgeable faculty, and good courses.  Extensive career fair twice a year is the best for employment opportunities.
cons: Very little diversity and no formal professional development instruction for graduate students.    Compared to other departments there is practically no overlap or collaboration with industry.   Little accountability for poor/absent mentorship. Early career faculty don't get enough support or funding, and late career faculty can hold outdated technological knowledge.

review_title: Different Units work with different levels of efficiency
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: It is a large research university with many different departments. The benefits of being in a diverse university community with a lot of young, energetic people around is great for entrepreneurial folks. A large amount of the students are also in science and engineering fields so that is of a big benefit for forging interdisciplinary connections. Great IT systems.
cons: Some of the administration is very slow with paperwork. Weather is not great for 6-7 months of the year. Also the public transport inside the town is good, but it is far from all major hub airports and the local airport in expensive.

review_title: Worked as Lecturer in a STEM department
job_title: Lecturer in State College, PA
pros: For basically an adjunct-like position this was really good.  I got health benefits, a decent salary, and a reasonable teaching schedule.  I got paid for the amount of teaching I did and I negotiated that at the beginning of the school year in my contract.  I mostly taught beginning level classes, which was fine because they are easy to prepare and take up more credits (= more money).  I left only because State College is in the middle of nowhere and my girlfriend was in another state.
cons: State College is isolated and you have to want to be in this area.  Also it is not a full time position.  It has to be renewed every year or two.

review_title: Good place to work just for a few years
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: Great university and excellent infrastructures and locations. State College is one of the safest places to live in the USA. Medical/Dental benefits are also excellent and generous. Professors and academic directors are always aware of the good work.
cons: The pay is very low, even though private industry sponsors most of the projects and Leader Investigators receive a good portion of it. Besides being low, the are never adjusted even for the annual inflation rate, which is just unfair. Things don't move very quickly and the opportunities to grow to upper levels are very very limited.

review_title: Good benefits, OK pay for Central PA
job_title: Anonymous Employee in University Park, PA
pros: There is certainly opportunity for growth at the University, but usually you have to completely change departments to do so. Often times there is little opportunity for growth within a Unit. Great benefits (medical, dental, vision) and time off. You can't beat the almost two weeks off around Christmas!
cons: There is a lot of waste at the University - especially with personnel. If you don't mind watching people that don't do their work be placed in a corner or promoted to get them out of the way - while still collecting a paycheck probably bigger than yours - then you'll be fine here. Penn State could conservatively fire 1/3 of the workforce (the unproductive 1/3) and not lose anything.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: Small town expenses and great place to live. Great libraries, and school system. The community is very safe. There are a lot of things to do in the town. It is very close to mountains and hikes and hence is great for people with liking for outdoor activities. The environment overall is very intellectually challenging if  you are able to find the right group and right set of people. The crime rate is extremely low. The school system is good too. Working in the university offers some degree of job security. It is a good place to retire and especially if one is towards the end of the career and planning on moving to a quieter place.
cons: It is not very close to any major cities

review_title: You have to be Clever to gain
job_title: in University Park, PA
pros: There are several departments and facilities. There is a large student community you can interact with and are good.
cons: Salary, position and promotion are very unsatisfactory. Like everywhere, the PIs try to exploit to the maximum extent, no ethics. Mostly people coming from abroad lack this commercial outlook and also due to their visa restrictions, get exploited. Most of the PIs themselves are mediocre level of researchers struggling for their own survival and beneftis, so will think about the benefit of students or employees only if benefiting the employees benefits themselves. Health insurance costs much more compared with universities in other states. Salaries of Postdocs /RAs are very less in comparison to other places.

review_title: For grad school, PSU is ok, but not great
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: I was a phd student. I found the students to be smart and hardworking. However, the faculty were out of touch. They were too focused on their research to notice that their students needed more help.
cons: The location could be better. The town is quite nice, though. It's just  a little too far from a big city. It's about a 4 hour drive to NYC, DC, or Philly.  For a little town, it's pretty good.  There is no visible poverty, for example. It's safe and has plenty of bars downtown.

review_title: Many departments have a good working culture that respects and the; Penn State Outreach and WPSU not good places to work
job_title: Manager in State College, PA
pros: If you get into a department that is managed well, It can be a great experience. I have many friends who work outside of Outreach and they love the collegiate atmosphere. They are having a tough time now with the  scandal but Penn State is not just a football school and eventually the university will come back better than before.
cons: Stay away from Outreach.  It is bloated at the top and they lay people off because they have to pay the directors high salaries.  It always seems that they never layoff highly paid managers, but they'll lay off worker bees

job_title: Service Desk Supervisor in State College, PA
pros: The ITS department at Penn State is a great place to work. Management is very willing to work with your strengths and build on your weaknesses. I have learned many new skills working as a Service Desk Consultant and Supervisor that I will value for the rest of my career. The working environment is very casual, but professional as well.
cons: I would like to see more advancement opportunity within the organization for student employees. I think that we can be utilized a bit more to help ITS as a whole and also to build our own resume a bit.

job_title: Programmer/Analyst in State College, PA
pros: Very flexible hours with work at home an option depending on what group you are in, and they have great benefits. The people are very friendly and easy to get along with, if not even somewhat odd, but in a fun way.
cons: Very decentralized being a university, so when you need stakeholder support or direction from the top, good luck getting it. Many ideas stall out before they even really get started because too many groups have equal power to veto or just don't give the support you need.

review_title: Great place to work and live
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in University Park, PA
pros: State College is a great place to live and it is safe, and people are very friendly. Penn State is a research-oriented university so people pay much weight on research, presentation, and graduate level studies. So there are plenty of opportunities to work with professors on research projects.
cons: Salaries may not be very competitive because the living expense is not very high. Life is a bit boring especially during the holiday break.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: Beautiful area, high quality research. High camaraderie among graduate students and other positive and supportive environment.
cons:
Penn state at large is frighteningly cultish and willing to look over immoral behavior (although I'm sure other large football schools suffer this problem). 
Computing cluster management is a disaster. One is better off running simulations on Amazon or Google or their own computer for a larger price than deal with ICS.
Poor undergraduate instruction in physics -- mostly organizational style. 
Mediocre to handling of graduate student grievances.
Particular faculty have far inappropriately large weight when it comes to graduate student applications.
Loudest voices among faculty appear to be the only ones heard, while not enough attention paid to the opinions of humbler and/or quieter but equally (if not more) qualified faculty.

review_title: Excellent University to pursue a degree at
job_title: in University Park, PA
pros:
- Prestigious, people know about Penn State internationally
- Large campus (could be a pro or a con)
- VERY safe community
- Nationally renown football program, as well as other sports
cons:
- Large campus (could be a pro or a con)
- Location, nothing else is around State College (could be a pro to some)
- Expensive for a state-sponsored university (especially if you are out-of-state)

review_title: I worked as a Student Consultant at the Computer Center while I was in school at Behrend.
job_title: Student Consultant in Erie, PA
pros: All student consultants who were hired know their stuff, so you could count on another consultant to help if you didn't know the solution to a problem a student/faculty member was having.
cons: Opening shifts were always hard to get to at 7:30 or 8:00 AM, but they were always easy because no students were awake to come get computer help. So this was a good time to do homework or whatever you needed to do.

review_title: A long trip from part time to full time.
job_title: Scanning Tech in University Park, PA
pros:
- Equipment. Penn State offers some of the most advanced equipment currently available to the private sector.
- Location. State College is a wonderfully safe little town with lots of charm.
- Students. Working with students can be a rewarding experience.
cons:
- Pay. It really isn't the best.
- Raises. Almost non-existent recently.
- Being wage payroll/adjunct. You may as well give up trying to move into a full time position from either of these.
- Management. The ones I have encountered are a little out of their element.

review_title: Best place I have ever worked.
job_title: Publication Specialist in University Park, PA
pros: Management was incredibly skilled, knowledgeable, and supportive. This is definitely a people-oriented place to work. They care about you and your family and will do everything in their power to make your job a place you want to come to every day.
cons: Low pay for the career field/skills. This is not true across the entire university, but despite the position being entry level, the pay was still not comparable to other entry level positions in the area.

review_title: Penn State is a good place to work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: Lots of opportunities for advancement.  Freedom to perform independent research with lots a funding available.  Great atmosphere with helpful people who are excited about science and want to collaborate on multiple projects.  Interdisciplinary research also a great plus, and there are a lot of great seminars available if want it advance your knowledge.
cons: State College is cold and cloudy all the time.  It is academia so depending on where you are working you can be low on funding.  If you are a tech you have to train rotation students, undergraduates, many of which do not stay with the lab for a long time.

review_title: Good job, ok co-workers, poor salary.
job_title: IT Specialist in University Park, PA
pros: I enjoyed helping people through their IT issues and felt very appreciated for my efforts.  It was an enjoyable job.
cons: My co-workers were not competent.  I worked harder than others and accomplished more in less time.  It made me unhappy over time because I felt like I was doing an unfair share of the work and not receiving any additional praise or compensation for my efforts.  The salary is very much below similar positions within the university as well as outside.

job_title: Research Associate in State College, PA
pros: The University Park campus, especially, has great infrastructure to support social science research.  Excellent benefits, supportive work environment, and great sense of community.  The integration between the colleges through University wide institutes and collaboratives to generate NIH grant submissions and promote interdisciplinary work is incredibly beneficial for researchers at all levels.
cons: Location is lovely IF you prefer a small college town and rural living and because of location, salaries for non-tenure(track) faculty and staff are not competitive with other areas of the US.  At times, it appears there is a lot of turnover in faculty because it is difficult to attract and keep researchers in the area.  Travel is often very difficult and limited.

review_title: I had a positive experience working on a part time basis for the center for sustainability within the University.
job_title: Videographer in University Park, PA
pros: It's a good work environment, everyone is friendly and helpful. The University has been around a long time and is very stable and orderly, but is also forward thinking and innovative, and this is reflected in its offices.
cons: Compensation is very modest, at least for part timers. Depending on what department or office you work in there may be a lot of red tape or bureaucracy to wade through when it comes to workplace accommodations, as with any large educational institution.

job_title: Academic Advisor in University Park, PA
pros:
The university is large enough where you there are a large number of opportunities to experience different things.  

The health benefits are outstanding. You'll get coverage for your entire family.

State College is a great place to live, especially if you have a family. It is safe and clean.
cons: Your experience will really depend on what area of the university you work in. I know some people that have had a horrible experience because of their supervisor. The salaries could be better. There isn't really a huge incentive to offer a large salary, because there aren't any comparable universities nearby.

review_title: The students are wonderful and eager to learn.  As a part-timer it's very sterile.  You come in and you leave.
job_title: Lecturer in Abington, PA
pros: The students respond well to good teaching. There is a professional atmosphere.
cons: There's no space for adjuncts. I was told I could meet with students in the hallway. The parking is terrible unless one arrives before the first class. The students are not used to coming to class or being on time, so there is an adjustment period as they learn the rules of my classroom.

review_title: Student working at the food commons
job_title: Student Manager in University Park, PA
pros:
- Easy application process for being a student employee
- Being a student, scheduling is very flexible and getting off from work due to school is easy
- Every Spring there's an opportunity to be promoted to student manager as long as you show drive in carrying your work
- The full-time employees are very nice people
- Good opportunity for students to meet other students
- Management is friendly and down-to-earth
cons:
- You will end up working with other students who may have never worked a job before or will lack any kind of motivation to actually do work
- Depending on how many student workers they hire, work can end up being super busy or really idle

review_title: Great Learning Opportunities, Not great for Hard Work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in University Park, PA
pros: The University has always supported learning experiences, and is very geared toward personal and professional development. Being a part of the University is a very fulfilling experience in terms of the value of the work that you do.
cons: As a University, salaries are "fair", but it's a race to the bottom. I've met more people who spend more time getting out of work than working, leaving others to consistently have to pick up the slack. There is no penalty for underperformance and performance simply gives you more work. Not great for those who like to work hard and be rewarded for it.

review_title: Great place to launch a career
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher in University Park, PA
pros: A top-rate research university that can provide an excellent work environment if you get the right post-doc position. If the post-doc you're considering is a good fit, this an excellent place to advance your skills and expand your network of contacts. Facilities and IT are by and large first rate.
cons: State College is a town geared toward undergrads and families, so don't expect a lot of excitement unless you generate it yourself. This is central Pennsylvania, and it can feel somewhat remote.The Sandusky scandal is a black eye for the university, in my opinion, but it doesn't appear to be having a major impact on the university's prospects in the short- or long-term.

review_title: A good academic adviser is extremely important and scholarships help offset costs
job_title: Graduate Student in University Park, PA
pros: With a good academic adviser, you are able to work independently and on topics that excite you with advice and guidance from your adviser.  If you get a good adviser, you are able to have a flexible schedule and are not required to show up from 8-5 everyday.  Most graduate students will also serve as teaching assistants for various professors.  Again, some professors make this an enjoyable experience, others tend to over-use their graduate students.
cons: Cost of living is high in the area so it's hard to save much from your assistantship and funding is hard to get for certain research projects.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in State College, PA
pros: most departments have great work/life balance. very generous time off.
cons: administration seems to think that COL here is very low and pays far less than market because of this. COL is not low. housing and gas are very costly here. your dollar won't go as far as you think it will considering that this is a town with basically no services.

review_title: If you're not immediately appreciated or have inside connections, don't waste your time.
job_title: Various IT Related Positions in State College, PA
pros: Benefits, Tuition Reduction, Waiting for retirement, 10/90 principle (if you fall in the 90).
cons: Entirely too much politics involved in the advancement of employees.

review_title: Enjoyable and challenging until you hit the plateau
job_title: Systems Administrator in University Park, PA
pros:
Biggest and one of the best employers in the area. IT people left other nearby companies to work for Penn State. Many who gain employment by the university stay and develop long careers in higher education.

Retirement benefits are strong: the university contributes 9% to a 403(b) plan or you can opt for the state employees pension plan. Health care benefits are mediocre. PTO is 24 days per year for full-time staff plus another 10 paid holidays. In my opinion, that is the best benefit of all.

Depending on the department, you may have many opportunities for professional development. I did, and enjoyed the travel to courses and conferences around the country.

I really enjoyed working with coworkers who wanted to work and had some life in them. However, there were too many folks who got in and then got lazy. They did the bare minimum and made work difficult for the rest.

Amongst good employees, there is a culture of pride in the work done and in serving the students and faculty so that Penn State could accomplish its mission.
cons: Compensation differs greatly from department to department for the same kind of job. Once you have mastered your job, if the management says there's no room for growth, the only way to stay challenged is to apply to other positions within the university or outside. There is no promotion plan. In the central IT unit, there are too many layers of management, making bureaucracy a real problem. It takes a long time to get things done. Good ideas often rot on the vine because of the slow nature of university management.

review_title: Best job on campus, better than most internships.
job_title: Student Consultant in Erie, PA
pros: Good pay, flexible hours, and once you've been on board for a while you have plenty of autonomy.  If you have technical knowledge you should absolutely try to apply for this position while studying at Penn State Behrend.
cons: Kind of frustrating having Main Campus rule over every one and every thing.  Sometimes you'll have a simple quick and cheap solution to a problem and will get ham stringed by University bureaucracy.  Just the nature of the beast I guess.

review_title: The management was bad for my health.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in State College, PA
pros:
Co-workers were fantastic.
Creative projects.
A willingness to hear you out on ideas and sometimes give you a shot at implementing them. 
Since the Sandusky scandal, things have been slowly improving.
cons:
Poor pay compared to industry standards; many employees didn't even earn a living wage for the region.
Class divisions between management and workers; I often felt like I was being treated like a second-class citizen.
Abuse of 'part-time' employees, who often worked 40 hours per week doing the same work as their 'full-time' peers with no benefits and lower wage.
Toxic management environment.  To put it bluntly, I was less shocked than I should have been by the Sandusky scandal.

job_title: PhD Student in State College, PA
pros: Huge campus with lots of resources, including the number of faculties, facilities, different majors. Quite and safe place to stay for scientific research. Many student activities and nice environment.
cons: Biology PhD program usually doesn't offer rotations and is lack of resources for rotation students. Keep of isolated small town which doesn't offer many job opportunities. Most of the companies in the career fair are not interested in biology PhD. Not very supportive environment for PhD students who are seeking for alternative careers outside of academia.

job_title: IT Manager in Erie, PA
pros: Stable, Challenging, progressive environment. Good benefits with a great family mentality. Really enjoy many of the people I get to work with. It is prestigious place to work. The faculty and students challenge us all to be constantly improving.
cons: Higher education is expensive and keeping costs down while providing a world class technology environment is challenging. Unfunded mandates by the central administration have huge impacts on our available funds.

job_title: Barista, Shift Supervisor in Erie, PA
pros: I loved my job working at Clark Café. Flexible hours for working around my class schedule and never had to work weekends. The work was fun and my coworkers were great. It is easy to get noticed if you are a hard worker and do no call off work or are constantly late.
cons: Some of the management that oversee Housing and Food Services at Behrend don't give Clark Café the attention it or its employees need. Often times the managers do not even look student employees in the eye whenever they come to visit, let alone say hi. You also don't always get the training that you need.

job_title: in University Park, PA
pros: Decent Salaries especially for the area.  Good working environment with the resources to do what is required to meet organizational needs.  I have a sense of pride that I an working for one of the premiere educational institutions in the world.  I am confident that the organization will be here for as long as I choose to be employed.
cons: Very large organizational structure can lead to variations in how the departments react to needs and changes. While the organization will likely always exist, the need for my position may not and there is little personal motivation to assist my reassigment if that becomes true.

job_title: Camera Op in State College, PA
pros: Amazing faculty and staff. Most are very kind and helpful, with you typical number of bad apples. Having worked in multiple departments, I think it is safe to say it is true University wide.
cons: If you are unfamiliar with the area, it is in what many would consider the middle of nowhere. If you love the country, a polite and welcoming community, and a moderately sized town, then this is your place. If you are looking for the hustle and bustle of big city living, this may not be your best bet. (although, you will still get plenty of that on football weekends)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in State College, PA
pros: Pros about working for Penn State University: Steady work environment, great people, wonderful benefits, standard hours, low-stress
cons: Cons about working for Penn State University: Salary is much lower than average, many projects are a "fire drill" for completion, too many people have a direct say in final products, not an environment where people say "no" which makes project completion a problem. "Trying to please everyone" is not a good work method

job_title: Administrative Assistant in State College, PA
pros:
* Lots of autonomy, the ability to make decisions in relative authority
* Great relationships between faculty and staff in the liberal arts
* Flexible scheduling often available during the slow summer season
* Opportunity to make a difference in the lives of students every day
cons:
* lots of paperwork and bureaucracy to get things done
* old, entrenched systems that are resistant to change or efficiency
* not many chances for advancement, not much movement out of more senior positions.

job_title: Research Associate in State College, PA
pros: Penn State is well-established and thus has many structures in place that smaller school do not have.  Most employees are friendly and helpful.
cons: Because the University is so large, sometimes it is difficult to figure out whose responsibility a task is.  This can lead to phone conversations that take you in circles.  There also seemed to be an enormous amount of rules and paperwork for payroll even for a part-time employee.

review_title: The environment where you are paid while learning.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: This is the environment where you are paid while learning. Depending to the department you are involved with the conditions may change, but the faculty is generally very supportive, and the work is paying itself when your work is recognized by conferences, journals.
cons: Since when you are a graduate assistant you are in late 20s or 30s it is time to have a family, but the income may not be enough to support a family.

review_title: Not all it was supposed to be.
job_title: Production in State College, PA
pros: Free education, but not in all Colleges. Beautiful campus. Great town. Many great people working for the University.
cons: You have to pay to park at your own job (in rural Central Pennsylvania). In my department, pay was much lower, and time off was minimal, compared to most other employees I knew working for this University and others.

job_title: Marketing Communications Specialist in University Park, PA
pros: Great insurance and retirement benefits, great tuition discount for employees, spouses, and dependents, interesting work, flexible scheduling, and a great environment for learning!
cons: Bad management can tend to thrive in this environment because the University is very willing to work with someone or reassign them rather than firing someone. In one unit where I worked, a manager with a lot of complaints was reassigned and then after a few years, reinstated back to management where the same problems arose. Luckily, once you have a job with the University, it is easy to transfer out of a unit with bad management to another with better management.

review_title: Mostly good, but sometimes frustrating...Like every job
job_title: Director of Development in State College, PA
pros: The people are great. I work in a highly professional department (some are excellent and have a strong national reputation, others are less so). Well resourced to do my job, access to professional development opportunities.
cons: Highly conservative campus, risk averse in the wrong ways - won't try new technologies, dated IT infrastructure and strong allegiance to the 'way we have always done it here', lacks receptivity to innovative ideas, cronyism still exists.

job_title: Research Associate in University Park, PA
pros: Great benefits, many opportunities for exploring different careers within the University, friendly people everywhere, possibility to work part time with full benefits
cons: Staff salaries are on a lower side, pay raises do not reflect the cost of living increases, there have been tendency not to replace workers (retirees, for example) and distributing their workload on others; the organization is very top-heavy with many redundant high-paying positions.

job_title: Instructional Designer in State College, PA
pros: Get to work with smart people (in some positions), have a big reach, learn constantly, stay young.
cons: Institutional bureaucracy; at the mercy of state legislators to some extent (who are not always particularly supportive); Protective fiefdoms, widely variable vision/leadership.

review_title: A great place for your career to die
job_title: Systems Administrator in State College, PA
pros: You do not have to perform, so if you want to coast for the rest of your career look no further.
cons:
Lots of legacy management appointments with little to no expertise in dealing with people.  
Not diverse, but the University is great at hiring mediocre people for middle management. 
The motto is We Are Penn State but that does not translate to workers. Many people are looking for their big opportunity because they have realized that getting your name in front of a lot of people is the only way to be compensated appropriately and/or move ahead. This creates a culture of people taking credit from colleagues or limiting their potential for recognition or advancement. It also causes some employees to finger point at others instead of taking accountability for their own flaws. The organization is a master class in how to make yourself look big while keeping others down. It has all the negative hallmarks of an extremely conservative organization.

Many projects go over budget or under-perform because middle management isn't thinking about the impact on students. There are vendors that are literally double charging the University or doing horrible work and they still have contracts with PSU because they've been there for a long time. The University does not view students as their #1 stakeholder but as a bank account. Look at schools like Rice University that use their endowment to create scholarships, I have no idea how PSU utilizes it's endowment.

review_title: Liberal Academia & Red Tape, but also Liberal Pay
job_title: (An Engineering/Technical Field) in State College, PA
pros:
Job Security. Once you get in the door, provided you're a reasonably good employee, you'll most likely be set for life. If you respect others, take your job seriously, and perform your duties well, you'll be just fine. You won't have to worry about lay offs, downsizing, or loss of contracts. Provided no major catastrophe occurs, academia is second only to government work for job security. And Penn State has done a great job securing its funding from the state and bringing in additional income and donations from students and other customers.

Health benefits. 90/10 Highmark is a great plan to be on in this day and age of the Obamacare disaster. Salary employees get these benefits rather quickly when they walk in the door, and wage employees get them after a designated number of hours (eg: a year or two).

Rich atmosphere of research and development that makes Centre County and all of the branch campus throughout Pennsylvania shine! When you work here, you're working under a very big, well-known name. That has a lot of pull that extends deep into the state and private sector. For example, Penn State employees get a 23% discount on line fees for Verizon wireless services, and if you buy a Dell computer for personal use, you also get a big discount. Just mentioning the name Penn State will often get you some respect/credibility from most of those living in the US.

Retirement. Hop on the state SERS plan. It's a state-funded employee retirement system that has some very good fail-safes in place. Financial gurus might argue for or against it, but for the average person out there, it's a good retirement plan to adopt. Of course you have to keep working for a Pennsylvania state agency to keep contributing to it, but it should be there in force when you retire. For those entertaining the idea of working at Penn State, please keep in mind that there are other private-sector retirement plans to choose from (you're not locked into SERS).

Liberal vacation and sick leave. Penn State gives employees a lot of leeway in helping them balance work and their personal lives.

Research is king here. Yes, this is a university, but this is also a business of research, development, and services contracted out to other agencies and businesses. Don't fret, because this is a good thing. The university has expanded beyond academics. They've utilized the power of their resources and branding to build a business and groundwork that underpins the traditional higher-education role. The academic and business sides of Penn State are now joined at the hip. They support one another. From Penn State University and branch campuses to Penn State Hershey and countless contracting services, that diverse framework helps us overcome recessions and funding downgrades.

Football and other athletic sports. This university dumps a lot into its Nittany Lions and athletic teams. If you're a fan of any sport, Penn State probably has you covered. The fan following stretches throughout Pennsylvania, and even into other states. So if you want to be at the heart of it, you'll be working for the right employer.
cons:
Penn State knows they're the primary employer in State College, let alone Centre County. Therefore they have a lot of leverage in dictating standards for pay and benefits. With that said, don't get me wrong, the benefits are good and the pay is very fair. But still, this bargaining chap of theirs has dampened larger corporations from dropping roots in Centre County and competing with Penn State for educated employees. And Penn State knows this. It's not necessarily their fault, but they take full advantage of it.

No ladder climbing here. I've learned that the best way to build your career and advanced at Penn State is to quite your current job and start another. Seriously. Advancement is laden with so much red tape that you'll be paddling at the same position for years until you even get the most narrow window to advance. It doesn't matter how well you preform or what level of ambition and dedication you have, once you start working here, you're stuck in that position until someone else takes pity on you and recommends some sort of promotion.

Red tape. There's a ton of it. You can't sneeze on a form without jumping through hoops to get it approved and sent through the proper channels. Some entities and departments have it easier than others. For example, my entity only has to deal with Penn State for HR and Networking/Phone, so we have it easy compared to others.

The culture: liberal BS that started in the 90s but continues and is even worse today. I'm talking about the hyper-sensitivity to office-place harassment, diversity & diversity training, hyper-environmentalism, "Penn State Recycles", and now the child safety documentation and exam we must process thanks to the reaction to Sandusky's perversion and torment of children. These liberal policies has completely changed departments of Penn State. One example is Purchasing. It's not just "Purchasing" anymore, it's "Supplier Diversity and Environmentally Responsible Purchasing". Yeah, that liberal BS is rampant in academia, but it's especially repulsive at Penn State. If you love hugging trees, proudly drive a hybrid or electric vehicle, and talk about your carbon footprint, then these policies may be a pro instead of a con. Either way, Penn State hemorrhages this stuff, so be warned. I've had to play along and keep a smile on my face through all of this. It's a little stifling, but it keeps you from being on the receiving end of these liberal policies.

Parking for employees can be a nightmare for some. You can only park in certain lots, and the parking fees come out of your salary. Worse, because this is a liberal campus, they really frown upon auto-based traffic while encouraging bicycle and pedestrian traffic. That's why driving and parking on campus is a royal PITA. If you do work here or plan to work here, then I hope you can work off-campus, where this won't be as great a concern. And remember, parking for those of significant clout (the higher-up positions) is fine. It's the rest of us who have to put up with poor parking, especially if you're unlucky enough to be quite far from a parking garage.

Computing. Nazi-like control over their networking/computing. If you're part of an entity that's separated from the campus, you may have more wiggle room, but if you're right on campus expect to have little computing flexibility. Granted, some corporations are even worse, but for a university, they're very strict. If you need any special privileges or functionality in your computing tasks, expect to wade through the red tape... that is if you're lucky enough to get approval for those exceptions.

job_title: Director of Development in State College, PA
pros: Community is tight knit, family oriented, diverse and the area is really beautiful. The DDAR team has great leadership and pays competitively for those in leadership roles.
