cons: Those in mid career positions are not paid quite as generously and it takes a lengthy period of time to advance within the organization because talented people stay there.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: Good pay, and understanding supervisors. Also an easy job to do while already being in college. They are pretty lenient with the hours you report, and almost no cross checking.
cons: Having to work at a public university, you have to be aware of what you are saying and who you are saying it to. A lot of your supervisors don't really work on the weekends while you have to.

review_title: Penn State is a great place to be for ambitious, positive people with a strong work ethic.
job_title: Associate Director in University Park, PA
pros: The benefits cannot be beat.  We get 24 days of vacation a year plus 7 holiday days at Christmas.  Also, the educational benefits for you, your partner and your children are very helpful in continuing your education or paying for a child's education. There are a lot of professional development opportunities and in my department, people are very willing to mentor you and help you learn more to get ahead. There are a lot of great resources and people to know on campus, including the students. As a result, town is full of great service opportunities and organizations where you can volunteer or enjoy the arts.
cons:
It is located in the middle of Pennsylvania.  It's 3.5 hours to NYC, Philadelphia, and DC so it takes a while to get to a place more diversity and a plethora of cultural opportunities. While the transplants to the area can be more inclusive in their thoughts and actions, the local culture is very close minded and can make some people feel very uncomfortable. If you don't like football, you'll need to get away or hide in your house a good eight weekends out of the year. 

Like any large organization, there is a beaurocracy in place that can be stifling. I guess it's necessary for keeping a system in place for thousands of employees, but sometimes it seems unfair and sometimes you see things that are wrong that won't change. If you are on a bad team or have a bad boss, you are better off finding a new job as it is rare for people to be reprimanded or get fired.

review_title: Great environment but not much challenge or opportunity for growth
job_title: Systems Administrator in State College, PA
pros:
The overall environment of Penn State is excellent. The university tends to feel like a community working together to produce high-quality education, and this is a good feeling. If you are working in the right department/position you can have a big impact on the tens of thousands of students or thousands of employees. Job security is high if you hold a full-time standing position. Resources available to faculty and staff are vast: excellent libraries, gyms/workout facilities, special interest or hobby clubs, intramural sports or spectating at any of the varsity sports, concerts and shows on campus, and more. The area surrounding the university includes several state parks, gamelands, trails for hiking and biking, hunting/fishing/etc. Cost of living in the area is fairly low.

Every department is different in terms of amount of work, stress level, pay, coworkers, etc. so it's hard to comment on many specifics related to employment.
cons: The university is generally well-staffed and in some departments, over-staffed. This can lead to some really slow days and a lot of dead wood occupying offices and cubicles to collect paychecks while others pick up the work. Once I learned my job, I didn't have much opportunity for new challenges, and I see this all around me in central IT. The org chart is difficult to navigate. If you are ambitious and want better opportunities and better pay, you need to apply to new jobs within PSU because promotions are not given. Old-fashioned silo hierarchies breed bureaucracy, squelch good and creative ideas from the worker bees, and cause tension in inter-departmental communications.

job_title: Representative in State College, PA
pros: Self manage, its a new company so the higher ups let you do more with projects.  making events is a lot of fun and getting people to join in is a lot of fun. Boss are super nice and try to be as helpful as they can.
cons: Self manage, you truly are alone, and it is really all up to you.  Getting people to take 5 minutes out of there day to sign up for a free website is harder than it sound, than again when you do get people to it feels great.

review_title: If you're looking for an IT staff position, stay away
job_title: IT in University Park, PA
pros: Probably the best employer in the area, which isn't saying much.  Reasonable but declining benefits.  If you are an outside hire you can bargain for a decent salary with a reasonable cost of living.  Decent life/work balance.  In general, coworkers are nice enough, some are excellent.  Opportunity to support higher ed, which is a laudable activity.  It is large enough that if you are in a different area you might have a totally different experience.  Move around in the university if you land in a bad spot.  It's also large enough that different professions deal with very different realities.
cons: Small raises.  Declining benefits.  Culture is caustic and toxic.  Constant interim leadership positions.  Expect to move your desk (or office if you are lucky enough to have one) more than once a year.  Expect to reorg at least once a year.  You will be reassigned to other organizations after your org is nuked and no longer exists.  Nepotism is everywhere.  Silver bullet mentality rules from above - They keep searching for that commercial product or practice that will fix things instead of involving staff in decision making processes, or even talking to staff to try and understand the root of problems.  Terrible leadership.  I mean REALLY bad.  Various egos larger than the campus rule the place.  Staff are treated as third class citizens by HR.  Faculty have the faculty senate in shared governance to represent them.  Students have an ombudsman and various governance to represent them.  Staff have squat.  Nada.  No governance or neutral grievance resolution process.

review_title: Good place to work and live
job_title: Graduate Assistant in State College, PA
pros: Working in a small and friendly city and pure campus environment, like the Penn State University, is a good balance for work and live. Safety environment and fresh air are the advantages which are hard to find everywhere.
cons: Somebody say here is "middle of nowhere", and this is true. So, if people enjoy competitive business busy life, here is not the place you want to stay.

job_title: Support Staff in University Park, PA
pros: There are some really nice people, working with students is rewarding. Benefits are good.
cons: I agree with other reviewers about the administration.  It's a "good 'ol boys" network.  If you are part of the "older white males in suites" clique, you are set.  If you aren't, you are most likely going to become a victim of politics -- especially if you have been there long enough to look like you might be a threat to the clique.  Pay is low, there are no raises -- all of the resources are going to cover the costs of the Sandusky scandal. If you have been there long enough to accrue a decent salary, you are in danger of being fired -- especially if you are an older woman -- your only options are to silently put up with the abuse or find another place to work.  HR is terrible.  Because of politics, they always sides with the "old white males in suites" clique.  Other departments don't want you because they don't want to pay your salary.  If you look at the current job postings you notice that the majority are in "Outreach."  That's not because people are retiring or because units are growing -- it's because they don't think twice about firing you. Penn State is an "employment at will" organization. You can be told you are no longer needed for any reason or no reason.  At least the unemployment folks recognize wrongful dismissal when they see it and you will get your full unemployment benefits!

review_title: Great place to do graduate work
job_title: Graduate Researcher in State College, PA
pros: Collaboration with other groups, departments, machine shop. Very open atmosphere, if you need help or advice can talk to any professor, student, or staff. Everyone is professional. Access to equipment and labs is incredible, walk into a lab, ask a few questions, propose a collaboration, buy them a beer/coffee and your are off.
cons: None, You make your own. Personal problems can happen, but its best to role with the punches and maintain the best working relationships you can. Being friendly and helpful has long term benefits, sometimes not immediately apparent.

review_title: Good place to work for if you like small towns where you will end up knowing many people
job_title: Wage Payroll Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: Short commute to work, decent public transport system, walking friendly campus with many food options close to work place. Several health/fitness options to choose and try out both as part time as well as full time employee or as student earlier.
cons: Lot of bureaucracy in everything, Very slow and resistant to change in operating procedures, very hierarchical systems

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: decent stipend for RA, the Prof. doesn't micromanage the TA's, very nice campus and town, many research opportunities, State College is a great area for outdoors activities, many bars and restaurants downtown
cons: mandatory training for many things, can fall through the cracks in a Uni this big, large campus means lots of walking (get a bike!), Penn State nickel and dimes the students

review_title: Interesting DoD signal processing work in submarine sonar if you can live with no management (Univ. of Texas)
job_title: Research Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
This *was* a research facility in Austin, Texas, where you could learn a lot about signal processing.  Interesting technical work in a niche field (high-frequency sonar for submarines);  offers some good signal processing and signal detection experience.  Great opportunities to attend graduate school for a master's degree (they'll pay).  You could even earn a Ph.D. (they'll pay) if you are truly dedicated and don't want a personal life. This is a division of The University of Texas at Austin, so close ties to higher-ed. 

Steady work.  A few opportunities still around to explore new technology and science;  they buy a lot of new computers to play with.  

Very flat management hierarchy:  only 4 people in the chain from bottom employee to division head;  Pay is decent but not great.  Some travel if you like that.
cons:
These days it's become just another software production company.  Turns out new feature set every 1-2 years, but very poor software quality.  Not really doing much research anymore in our department;  just writing code to make more GUIs.  Morale is low.  No Q/A, unit testing, code reviews, detailed design, or coding standards -- just "slapped-together" software that meets minimum requirements.  Folks have lost a lot of pride in what they do these days.

Micro-management in this division;  engineers pushed into management roles with no training;  management has a difficult time communicating the project vision, status, and requirements to engineers.  Too often people discover they have a product or delivery due in just a few days or weeks because of poor planning by and communication from management.  

No bonuses or stock options.  Health care benefits are good but seem pricey  (about $6k/year for a family after UT kicks in their part).  Very little continuing education offered except the opportunity to go to Univ. of Texas for a degree (bachelors, masters, and Ph.D.)

review_title: A good place to do research
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in State College, PA
pros: Exciting research in my department, abundant facilities, good atmosphere, good students
cons: Some aging buildings need fixing up, IT staff a bit undertrained

review_title: Great place if you enjoy small town America!
job_title: Administrative Support Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: Great work environment and good benefits. A large number of employees have worked here for 30+ years. Small University town makes commuting to work a breeze. Pennsylvanians are friendly. Employees voluntarily move to other departments every 4 to 5 years for a change of scene.
cons: All processes seem to be cast in stone. This attitude discourages people from showing initiative. Too much bureaucracy. Trying to make an important decision quickly is never possible as everything of significance has to be run by a number of people. People are territorial about their work.

review_title: Really nice people and the students are the best
job_title: Faculty in Monaca, PA
pros: PSU Beaver has a beautiful and scenic campus.  The staff and faculty are very open and friendly.  It is like a second family.  There are many opportunities to get involved.  Excellent Wellness Center.  Laid-back environment.
cons: It is a pretty small campus so if you like a big corporate headquarters environment for work, you may not be a good fit here.

job_title: Writing Tutor in Erie, PA
pros: Penn State treats its employees with so much respect and it is great to have the flexibility (as a student) to work around my class schedule. I enjoy being a writing tutor because it is an opportunity to meet students from many different majors and backgrounds.
cons: My hours depend on the demand for writing tutors. For example, if there aren't many writing assignments due that week, students don't schedule appointments that much.

review_title: Good student, reliable, fast learner, crave knowledge, work well with authority
job_title: Student for Clinical Psychologist in Penn State University, PA
pros: I'm educated, i"m a great employee, I can work independently, and I do well working as a team. I worked with the public for years as a server; so I can deal with people who are in a bad mood. I was a lead server teaching new hires on how to work micros and the personality they needed to uphold. Being a lead at a fine dining restaurant located at the casino, it was't uncommon for people to be upset losing a lot of money. I loved working their but they shut down the Pacer's Clubhouse  after the casino's extension. / When I was attending PSU I also went and did training at VRC ( Victims Resource Center) Being able to help others is the most rewarding thing I've ever done.
cons: I didn't have any downsides working at PSU, because I was a student.I did and do have a pet peeve when people don't do what they are told/assigned to do , and come in class early before the professor comes in, and they have a friend in the class who allows them to copy off the assignment. I guess that upsets me because I found out I was pregnant while in school but never missed a day went above and beyond what was asked of me . and I missed 2 days after having my son. I just don't like to see people float by when others work so hard to get where they are. But, I'v come to terms that's life, and I'm proud of myself for doing my job plus I love what I was in school for. I do plan to further my education. " A WISE MAN KNOWS NOTHING"

review_title: Lots of inefficiencies but Penn State is willing to change, just takes some effort
job_title: IT Consultant in State College, PA
pros: There is a large number of passionate and motivated people who want to make a difference by making student's lives and experience better. There are a large number of resources available to tab into to get things done.
cons: Like a lot of large organizations, it can be a bureaucratic headache. There can be some unfairness across different departments where one supervisor might give more pay, better evaluations, more flexibility than another supervisor for the same or worse employees.

review_title: Full of opportunities to do happy research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: In IST, your research direction can be very versatile. Totally depending on the type of your advisor, you'll feel either very pushed or very free to do your research here. Personally, I find myself really enjoying this work atmosphere - flexible hours, get timely and good-quality feedback on whatever I produce, have lots of excellent collaborators.
cons: It's a small village here; you have to find your ways to get involved in activities. Pay is also very little, although the consumption level is also low (e.g. most apartment rentals cost less than $500/mo)

job_title: in University Park, PA
pros: Tuition assistance of 75% off (tuition only).  Time off is okay for first year (12 hours VC acquired per month up to 190 hours.  Decent health coverage although everything is going up this year which eats up any kind of yearly raise.
cons: You must go to PSU for the tuition reimbursement to kick in.  It is unlike many other universities that are part of a consortium that you can switch to.  typically, not the highest pay in Higher Ed.

job_title: Lead Programmer Analyst III in University Park, PA
pros:
Benefits are good but they have been reduced greatly over the years.  Insurance costs continue to rise with higher deductibles.  (PSU is self insured with Highmark managing)

Great retirement packages (especially if you go with the State retirement as the government controls window opportunities).  

Depending on the unit, flexible schedules and work from home opportunities are available.  It can change greatly with a change in management though.  So a colleague may be able to do it but when you wish to start, a different manager can deny it.  There are no guarantees.

Free opportunities for developmental activities are available.  Does not guarantee that you get work time to complete.

If you have children looking to go to PSU, tuition discount offered is 75% on just tuition.  Room and board are expensive.
cons:
Low wages.
At one time, those in IT were highly encouraged to attend conferences to develop current knowledge of IT in higher education.  This doesn't happen now.  Management attends and sometimes brings back information.  
They charge for parking for employees.  Often employees need to park up to six blocks away from work location at almost $40 a month.  Time to walk is not included in work time so prepare for it.
Opportunity to grow within current area is very limited.  They do not promote within any more.  Jobs go to the public before allowing internal candidates to apply and be interviewed.  Some employees will leave the University for a short time and come back.  They tend to make more money this way.  If you stay for a long time, you never reach even the mid-range of the salary for the position level.
Yearly pay raises in the past 10 years or so have been limited to 1-2% on average.

review_title: Large village unto itself - Work experiences will vary greatly by area
job_title: Senior Project Manager in University Park, PA
pros:
Excellent educational community.  On campus there is a diverse and accepting population and a strong ethic towards volunteerism and giving of time and talent towards charity efforts.

The students and the mission of the University provide a great sense of contributing towards something valuable.  You have the opportunity to make a positive impact on young lives and returning veterans and adults.  The enthusiasm of the student body is encouraging.

The range and depth of academic expertise across a very wide range of disciplines is impressive and overflows into local life with plays, music concerts, science talks in the local draft pubs, and plenty of other ways in which the level of expertise that comes to Penn State enriches the local community.

It is a small, isolated area, however if you love mountains and lakes and fishing and hiking, there is a large percentage of the population that is very active in all that this area offers for outdoor adventures.  There is a lot of energy for environmental activism and conservation; responsible hunting, fishing and wildlife management; and public transportation and bike trail options are fantastic.
cons:
The salaries are low compared to other opportunities.  That used to be offset by an excellent benefits packages and opportunities for flexible work arrangements, however budgetary constraints recently have seen those other benefits decline.

There are areas of the University (as would be true in any large educational institution) where there is a very toxic workplace.  Do check first to see if there have been a series of complaints filed against certain behaviors, and if they've been reported, believe them before accepting a job.  Know that there are areas where serious personnel problems do exist.

Very difficult bureaucracy to navigate, and it keeps itself perpetuated.  That bureaucracy is also part of an ingrained "good-ol-boy" system that the University is working very consistently to address in a positive manner.  I've seen clear examples of times when management doesn't hire or bring in new talent that may have physical disabilities or may be the wrong gender and reporting violations of federal laws is still discouraged in certain units.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Altoona, PA
pros: Smart students and academic freedom.
cons: Low pay and utter lack of respect.  You are just a warm body to these folks.

review_title: Great Opportunities and People, Lots of Bureaucracy
job_title: Machine Learning Engineer in State College, PA
pros: I will be eternally grateful for the people I have met and the technology that I have been introduced to.
cons: The sheer size of the university and its various departments leads to a large amount of bureaucratic roadblocks, from stopping research lab-related trips to wait for forms to keeping track of every minute worked or not worked during certain trips or events. It's understandable for the diversity of research going on at different departments in research labs, but it leaves a lot of people in limbo sometimes.

job_title: Utility Worker in Erie, PA
pros: It's a job that pays more than minimum. There is the occasional free meal, and it's better than many other places.
cons: "Corporate" politics rule, nothing can really get done with out going through ~15 committees approval and anything new takes forever to get done. By the time it gets through all that it's out dated and the generally know to be the wrong way to do things, but they use it anyways.

job_title: Prefer Not To Say in University Park, PA
pros: If you're looking for a place to settle down and work for 10 or 20 years, you've found it. Global mission, wide exposure to numerous technologies, surrounded by creativity, low stress, lots of holiday and vacation time.
cons: Death by committee, lack of executive spine in countering abuse of tenure by spoiled faculty (minority), occasional run in with blind arrogance, faculty rarely show respect for staff in key decisions.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: make your own hours, so it is very convenient. Gets you much more one on one time with professors, allows the large school to seem smaller from knowing many more faculty members.
cons: balancing high stress work with school can be difficult, but you can work most any hours so it makes it easier to manage. Independent work most of the times

review_title: Penn State is a great place to do research
job_title: Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: Great place to do serious multi-disciplinary research. Excellent facilities, renowned faculty and competent technical staff.  People all around are willing to help acheive your research goals.
cons: People take long vacations or out of office for extended period of time. I have seen people leave as early as 3.30 pm! Too many rules and regulations to follow while doing research. Parking rules are outrageous .

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros:
- Very flexible hours.
- Diverse graduate student population.
- Strong engineering programs.
- Respected faculty.
- Numerous opportunites to get involved within and outside of academic interests.
cons:
- Graduate student research often comes down to $$$ and the bottom line.
- Location in the middle of no-where, PA.
- Lack of proximity to large cities.
- Rowdy, and often unruly, undergraduate population.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: Penn State is a very large school, so there is a ton of opportunity for research and funding. For the most part, any class you have interest in is going to be offered, even if it may not be exactly in your department. Most of the professors I have interacted with are very nice and helpful.
cons: Like all universities, it is very research driven, often at the expense of teaching quality. That is not to say that the professors are poor instructors, it is just quite apparent that research is the first priority.

review_title: Physics 212 Teaching Assistant at Penn State
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in State College, PA
pros: Penn State science, especially physics, is very concerned with helping their students learn and succeed. It was very rewarding working in this type of dynamic environment.
cons: If you get bored being in a rural area, Penn State may not be for you. However, the downtown area feels much like the downtown of a small city and the nature surrounding the university is wonderful.

review_title: Great Job to Earn Money and Challenge Yourself
job_title: Barista in University Park, PA
pros: Keeps you extremely active and engaged as it is constantly busy. The managers and student coworkers make the job so enjoyable and memorable.
cons: In the beginning, they offer a lot of pay increase incentives, but their are a lot of loopholes to get around rewarding loyal and good workers. Never miss a sick day if you can get around it as it will prevent an increase. If you are not accustomed to working in a busy hospitality environment you will have to learn to work quickly and efficiently.

review_title: Good job for a student- Flexible hours
job_title: Math Grader in University Park, PA
pros: I enjoyed working as a math grader at Penn State for three years as an undergraduate student.  The hours were flexible since I graded papers at my apartment and just turned in my papers at the end of the week.
cons: Some professors that I worked with did not have a grasp of time and often asked for too many problems to be graded per homework assignment.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: From the university stipend I receive as a student, I can easily support myself in State College PA. They also provide great health, dental and vision insurance. Numerous research programs to pick from.
cons: The graduate student is highly dependent on who you as your adviser. It could be awesome but it could also be depressing. Talk to current graduate students to find out what it is like.

job_title: in State College, PA
pros: I found that Penn State offered employees a very flexible schedule, simple and easy ways to advance your position, and the payment was satisfactory.
cons: My employers at Penn State were not understanding when it came to balancing work life/non-work life. I went on a leave of absence due to medical reasons and my excused absences were not "valid" apparently.

job_title: Research Technologist in University Park, PA
pros: Positions are very laid back and bosses are flexible.
cons: Pay is low and you will not be challenged.  The laid back culture promotes laziness and raises are given according to seniority instead of performance; again promoting greater laziness.  Wayyy too many employees for the amount of work that needs to be done....walk around and see how many people are doing nothing vs. working.  It's astonishing.

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: My department at Penn State was very flexible with me as a graduate student. They accommodated maternity leave with no questions asked (paid maternity leave is pretty rare for grad students). The health insurance is excellent, and I felt fairly paid for the work I did for the department.
cons: It did seem like there was a high rate of attrition among women. I think the university should also work on paying graduate students more to teach summer courses- or at least equalizing it more across departments.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Camp Hill, PA
pros:
I have worked at PSH as a research assistant during my senior year. some of the good things:
- Reachable Professors. 
- Good staff. 
- Great opportunities for undergraduate students looking to enhance their research skills.
cons:
- Pay rate is very law.
- Not enough facilities for research work. 
- Benefits are limited and cost a lot to have them. 
- Food is so expensive and limited choices.

review_title: Penn State: A lot of unrealized potential
job_title: Professor in University Park, PA
pros: Nice place to live. Pleasant work environment. Flexible time requirements. Ability to self-direct job trajectory.
cons: Paternalistic administration. Expensive health benefits. Ill-defined promotion criteria. Administrators who are unable to judge quality.

review_title: Positive but concerned about a lack of management focus and direction.
job_title: in Erie, PA
pros: A nice mix of teaching and research
cons:
Research expectations are unclear. Expectations for promotion are unclear. The college leadership needs to take a more active and visible role in management.
Enrollment is a concern but the management is not taking an active role in assessing enrollment or programs. The current approach seems to involve chasing fads and popular trends to boost enrollment rather than focus on building for long term growth.

job_title: UI/User Experience Designer in University Park, PA
pros: Flexible work hours and lots of vacation.
cons: Many people are just there to collect a paycheck, which makes doing your job much more difficult if you are passionate about your work.

review_title: Good job for very busy students
job_title: Tech Teaching Assistant in State College, PA
pros:
Flexible hours
On the job training
Able to network with faculty
Good student job for full time students
Work as little or as much as your schedule requires
cons:
Pay is lower than one would expect from a large university.
The work hours are also very low, usually 3-4 per week max. Good for most students, but if you want to make any real money look elsewhere.

job_title: Systems Administrator in University Park, PA
pros: Benefits package is pretty good.  The medical plan has been decreasing over time and the prescription plan isn't great at all.
cons: Political red tape is horrendous.  There is a lot of waste that goes on within the university and it is frustrating.  There is also almost no room for promotions and forget bonuses and employee appreciation.

review_title: Penn State University is an excellent research center for a lot of majors.
job_title: Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: The best of Penn State has one of the best advising professors that can guide their students to achieve their goals.
cons: One of the things that needs some work is the compensation and benefits. Since I am not a full time employee, I don't get to have any benefits other than the research experience.

review_title: Grad student in the Huck Institute of Life Sciences
job_title: NSF Graduate Research Fellow in State College, PA
pros: Great resources for research in terms of both lab facilities and digital journal access, decent medical, dental and vision insurance for graduate students
cons: Disorganized and confusing administration with mash-up of departments, institutes, etc. Lots of redundant paperwork. For those of us on multi-year contracts, each year is like groundhog day with having to essentially be a new employee all over again, which can be frustrating, especially when you're in your third or fourth year and someone says they have no record of you.

job_title: in State College, PA
pros: It is  a great place to do science. Professors are top experts in their field. Nice campus area. Smart students.
cons: Administration is not so competent. Administrative staff is bad.  Benefits are not so good compared to other places. Gym and sport facilities could be better.

review_title: The best Agricultural experience of my life.
job_title: Laborer in New Alexandria, PA
pros:
Hard work that you feel proud of after you have completed a task. 
The physical labor allows you to stay in great physical shape.
You get a lot of hours especially in the Summer.
cons:
Pay is not very good.
Job tasks can sometimes seem unconventional
High risk for injury on the job.
Working with chemicals all day can leave you smelling like pesticides when you go home.

review_title: Great job to have while in college. Great benifits
job_title: in University Park, PA
pros: Helps with personal development and people skills. If you want a job on campus and you want to work to develop freshman/sophomore aged college kids, this job is for you.
cons: Maturity level of the students your life with is annoying. I hate having to wake up just to settle a conflict in the middle of the night.

job_title: in Katy, TX
pros:
Lots of possibilities for collaboration with other faculty and department.
Good industry connections for companies in the east coast. 
Good location of you like outdoor activities.
cons:
State college is a small college town. Because it is a college town it is relatively expensive. 
Stipends for graduate students is dependent on department. 
Tuition is high and it keeps on increasing every year.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: It was a nice experience and I enjoyed all of the people. I also got good compensation and the job engaged my mind. overall I was able to come out of it with good practical experience.
cons: I did not get as many hours as I would have liked but it was a temporary position so It should have been expected.

review_title: Working for the ITS Consulting group at PSU was great!
job_title: ITS Lab Consultant in University Park, PA
pros: The staff was very kind and did not run into many troubles when helping others. You get to schedule your work hours however you want, if it is available. So there are always work arounds.
cons: You need to be patient sometimes, which is normal, but it can be frustrating sometimes. And even though scheduling your hours can be great, that can be frustrating as well, but it's nothing that can't be handled.

job_title: Adjunct Lecturer in State College, PA
pros:
Flexible hours outside of class teaching time.
Professional development opportunities.
Collaborations with fellow teachers. 
Canvas is a good tool as well as turn it in.
I can't think of any other pros for this position.
cons: Unreliable renewal of teaching assignments. No benefits, even if teaching in two or more programs equaling full time.  It is frustrating to not have an office as well. Parking is a pain.

job_title: Director in University Park, PA
pros: Work life balance and benefits are great.  State College is an exceptional place to work, live, and raise a family.
cons: Academia can be slow, so if you like a fast-paced environment, this might not be the place for you.  Faculty have more opportunities than staff in my opinion.

review_title: I had a great time working as an Resident Assistant
job_title: Resident Assistant in State College, PA
pros: The culture is really great.  You get free room and board and a stipend of about 500 per semester.  It was fun working with freshmen.
cons: The process of becoming a RA is a year-long process and you are not guaranteed a position.  Some of the staff can be hard to track down and negotiate with.  They seem to be stuck doing the same thing over over again.

job_title: AUDIT LIAISON (Accountant IV) in State College, PA
pros: Was able to review the great applied research being performed by engineers that directly contributes to national security and manufacturing technology,
cons: The Applied Research Laboratory Business Operations had a culture that was not a good follow on opportunity to the numerous other high performing organizations that I had worked for previously.

review_title: Inbred culture that creates a culture of following instead of leading
job_title: Outreach Associate in State College, PA
pros: Penn State's extrensic benefits are top-notch. Retirement, healthcare, and vacation time are all very generous.
cons: Organization is very fragmented.  In non-academic jobs, there is no career path (despite what HR tells you). When you move from one department to another, they treat you as if you are coming from an entirely different company and starting over.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in State College, PA
pros: Interesting work, strong sense of community. It is definitely a big university but can be made to feel small by making friends with small subgroups such as work colleagues or students from a club/organization.
cons: Somewhat isolated location. You have to be willing to live in Central Pennsylvania and know there is almost nothing around you for a couple hours.

review_title: University has good infrastructure to support students.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: In terms of access to equipment for scientific research, they have excellent facilities that are staffed by real pros.  Excellent health care coverage and new health center on campus.
cons: Expectations are very high for research output, but that varies with individual professors.  Gripes that basically come with being a graduate student-- we are undervalued and over worked.

job_title: Student Manager in State College, PA
pros: Networking, availability to advance your skill set, and flexibility around class schedule.  Benefits include employee meals and the job is a great resume builder.
cons: The staffing is generally on the short side due to low retention rates of student workers.  Raises are limited, although they are offered to those who show effort.

review_title: Benefits well above private industry. Mediocre salary
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bellefonte, PA
pros: Benefits are extremely good.  Health, time off, and flexibility are second to none.  The university is keeping costs as low as possible.
cons: Due to good benefits, salaries are behind comparatively.  Cost of living much higher due to university presence in the area and salaries don't meet these costs.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros:
Benefits are great as a single graduate student. 
Large university environment encourages lateral movement
cons:
Location - Large undergraduate population leads to shenanigans and it is a relatively remote location. 
Outreach opportunities for children 18 and under are inhibited by extensive background checks and training.
Penn State has an odd culture of pulling from their own crop when looking for management. Very rarely do they bring in outsiders (which is important for growth and advancement).

job_title: IT Help Desk Technician in State College, PA
pros: This was a part-time nights/weekends position that gave me plenty of time to work on my graduate degree while on call.  I was able to get out and interact with parts of the College that I probably wouldn't have otherwise.
cons: The end of semester "crunch" is to be expected, however supporting students and staff while trying to finish my own projects got a bit daunting.  I would recommend careful planning and project management to anyone in a similar position.

job_title: Adj Professor in Altoona, PA
pros: Psu is a good place to work, good options and good advancement ops.  Altoona is a great campus and has good students.
cons: Not really any complaints, just the normal beuracracy an having to deal with accreditation.  Just finishing my first year hear in three divisions.

job_title: Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: The program allows students to balance work with classwork without having an ill effect on either. The staff is very friendly and always willing to provide opportunities for the student to succeed.
cons: It is difficult for a lot of students to find these research opportunities. Usually a professor will guide you towards a project they are working on.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in State College, PA
pros: Good student healthcare with options for medical,dental, and eye. Can be used to knock out graduate course studies until you join a research lab for your thesis work.
cons: Hours and work-load depend on the teaching assignment. So some assignments are easy, while others are more hands-on and will require much longer than the 20 hours your paid for.

review_title: Very positive experience so far working with World Campus: employees dedicated to students, good morale, good management
job_title: Admissions Counselor in University Park, PA
pros: Amazing students and great opportunities to work with them, assisting adult learners and military students, good advancement opportunities within in World Campus and Penn State, good management - generally very dedicated to employees' wellbeing, good morale, great job security
cons: Little to no face-to-face contact with students, online education still skeptically viewed by public, veiled feeling of being cash cow for Penn State

review_title: I'm was an Undergrad Teaching Assistant
job_title: Teaching Assistant in State College, PA
pros: I loved working an as Undergrad Teaching Assistant. This way I was helping other students to understand the subject matter and preparing myself for professional life.
cons: I would say there were not any down side of working as an Undergrad TA. There is always a level of difficulty in any kind of work and best of us are who overcome that difficulty.

job_title: Research Technologist II in University Park, PA
pros:
Often flexible schedule (based on laboratory Primary Investigator).
Location great for those of us that don't like cities. State College offers much more cultural & recreational opportunities than any other town its size.
Holidays and vacation generous.
cons:
Department to department policies somewhat disjointed, but Penn State is in process of centralizing HR. 
Don't expect to park close to your building. 
You are in an academic research environment so you will receive much lower salary than in private sector research.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Beaver, PA
pros: Amazing benefits and casual work environment. Penn State is very good to its employees no matter what department they work in.
cons: Some of the politics of working for a state college can be frustrating. Sometimes things take a while to be completed because it has to go through so many people.

job_title: Library Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: The sceduling was very flexible, the people were friendly and the application process was extremly simple with a short period of time between application and interview and between interview and offer.
cons: The only real issue was that the compensation was poor. If you do work study, which I did not, you can receive a decent wage. However, part time student employies make between 7 and 8 dollars an hour which is not competative in this town.

job_title: Student Worker in State College, PA
pros: reliable schedule. Can easily pick up extra shifts when needed. potential for meeting new friends. growth in student management positions.
cons: Often understaffed. Student workers often do the task of 2.5 people, but do not get paid for it. closing shift does not end until after the store is cleaned. If your shifts ends at 12:30 you may get out between 12:45 and 1:30 am!

review_title: Your hours are made of rubber
job_title: Student Computer Technician in University Park, PA
pros:
No hour minimum, 40 hour maximum per week
Extremely flexible hours
Easy to substitute shifts
Pay premium for overnight shifts
Full-Time employees are friendly and accommodating
Paid training days
cons:
Management is going through changes, Interferes with the workflow
Always some sort of crisis going on
Very easy to get sick (Handling dozens of other people's computers in a confined space)

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Erie, PA
pros: Penn State has a great community that really cares about each other.  The work day is very flexible, so you can take some time off in the afternoon if you need and can work later at night or on weekends to make up for it.
cons: The university makes you pay for parking even if you are an employee.  Also, food choices in and around campus are limited, and dining on the school is expensive.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Penn State University, PA
pros: My program is excellent.  I'm supposed to be working 20 hours a week but it's more like 10-15 hours.  My advisor is completely supportive and understanding of obstacles like illness and classwork.
cons: The salary is still really low.  Luckily, I have a federal grant and summer teaching to make up the difference, but that's not true for everyone.

review_title: Great place to work with excellent benefits
job_title: Marketing Strategy Specialist in State College, PA
pros:
- Good company culture and brand
- Smart people at the office
- Campus is beautiful
- Excellent benefits
- Lots of room for growth and advancement
cons:
- Pay lower than industry standards (but it's really the only place to work in the area, so what do you expect)?
- Sometimes a little behind business best practices

review_title: My personal experience working at Penn State as a STEM peer tutor
job_title: STEM Tutor in Penn State University, PA
pros:
- This job is nice if you enjoy working with, and helping students with questions regarding course content of courses that you want to tutor. 
- In helping other students, you improve your own knowledge on content
- When there aren't students seeking help, you are able to do your own coursework during the downtime
cons: - There really weren't any major things I disliked about working this job

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in State College, PA
pros:
1. Good employee benefits: health, eye and dental insurance, paid leaves and sick leaves.
2. The Pennstate Postdoc Society, organizes many career development events targeted for the postdocs. 
3. A very good international faculty advising team that maintains your work status.
4. State college is one of the safest in the country
5. The community is very friendly towards foreign nationals
cons:
1. State college is a small college town
2.  Very far from big cities like Pittsburg and Philadelphia

job_title: Helpdesk Consultant in University Park, PA
pros: I currently work for Penn State's College of Earth and Mineral Sciences IT department, and i absolutely love it here. It's been a great job while i have been in college, good pay, good experience, and management always gives you the opportunity to learn. That's what i liked most about it, i was able to sharpen my skills and learn and apply new ones.
cons: None that i can say

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Wayne, PA
pros: Great community and resources. There is a great amount of energy during the school year due to the undergraduate students. It's great to see so many talented people in one small town.
cons: I would not recommend to anyone that loves urban living. Main campus is remote and can get boring after the initial honeymoon phase.  Communication between departments is nearly impossible and there is little efforts made to encourage collaboration in that way.

job_title: in University Park, PA
pros: Good health insurance coverage offered for graduate assistants.  Many University-level resources available.
cons: Graduate experience very dependent on your adviser and/or Department/Program.  Choose who you work with carefully!

job_title: IT Service Desk in University Park, PA
pros: Flexible scheduling, decent pay for students, homey management and very focused on work place environment for people who have been around for a while.
cons: The job is stressful as are all service desk positions. The training materials are weak and certainly need to be updated and made to contend with industry standards. This is currently a focus of management

review_title: A great place to live and work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: Happy Valley is beautiful and the people are so friendly.  IT's a great work environment for a graduate fellow in sciences since it is so strong in the STEM fields.   There is no "bad" part of town, it's very safe.
cons: getting around during the year when the undergrads are present is a little tough but it is what you would expect at a huge college town.

job_title: Assistant Professor in State College, PA
pros: Great place to share ideas with others in different departments. Wonderful libraries with excellent online resources. Good intellectual collaboration.
cons: Tough on adjuncts and fixed term faculty with low wages for work. Non tenure track have difficult time working above low wages due to number of students in classes and amount paid per class. Inconsistent pay rates in colleges implies little value in some colleges.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: The administrative assistants are very helpful and knowledgeable. There has been attempts at improving the program at the department level.
cons: Your experience will depend largely on your adviser/PI, which can vary greatly. Large turnover rate at the graduate office also makes it difficult to get additional information.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: Campus environment and facilities are great and it is safe for travel if you have to work late at night. Decent pay and great health benefits for graduate students (in STEM). Research quality and work/life balance depends on the advisor (professor) that you work for. Talk to the graduate students in the lab before you decide on joining any lab.
cons: Lots of politics in my department. Very few professors actually care for the graduate students.

job_title: Associate Professor in Harrisburg, PA
pros: Nothing in real terms, waste of life! Salary is about average, but what you use, if you are not values as an employee.
cons:
PSU administrators serve the interests of all the greedy people who run as Board of Trustees! To increase liquor sales in State College. To waste money bu inflated budgets on projects that benefit their surrogates. 


ABSOLUTELY pathetic, real meaning of P!

You can survive only if you lick boots of administrators! Absolute dictatorship, no value for hard work.

review_title: A great place to work and stay
job_title: Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros:
Penn State is one of the best research public university, and has many resources for graduate students to conduct quality research.
People in the department and in the university are very nice and helpful, and are usually supportive for students to conduct their own research, but also have high requirement for the quality.
cons: Quite little town, far away from big cities. Not many industrial intern or working opportunities in local area.

job_title: in State College, PA
pros: Great networking opportunities. Almost everyone knows someone within Penn State. And there are lots of fields to work in, but not many opportunities within each department to move up.
cons: Within the restaurant department there is a strong lack of management. Almost non-existent and a high turn over of employees including management.

review_title: Great place to learn and live.
job_title: Teaching Assistant in State College, PA
pros: Quiet, beautiful countryside. Good academic reputation and great professors. Generally a good, typical state university. Some departments like geo-science is particularly strong.
cons: Far from cities. Too quiet in holidays. Buses reduce services in holidays so it will be difficult for anyone who do not own a car. Prices of goods are about 1.2 times higher than the cities nearby, about 2 time higher than in big cities like NY, Houston.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: You can choose which project you want to involve and be able to interact with the professor directly. My summer research was paid 1500/month but it depends on how much funding your professor has. They have extremely good instruments and you can basically run every experiment you'd like to preformed.
cons: The labs here are different from commercial labs, so find an internship instead if you want to get more industry experiences.

review_title: Diverse job that keeps you on your toes!
job_title: Technology Manager in State College, PA
pros: 75% off tuition education benefits.  Good amount of vacation and sick days.
cons: Less competitive salary.  A lot of political drama.

job_title: Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: Great university, freedom to express your skills and plenty of top-notch resources to achieve them. There are great collaborative environment, good professors, students, and staff members.
cons: Some academic resources are outdated, and they are being revamped currently. More attention can be given to parking resources for research assistants

job_title: Associate Professor in Altoona, PA
pros: Great sense of community among colleagues. Plenty of opportunities to impact students. Flexible schedule.
cons: Wage stagnation over several years has caused many salaries to flat-line. Little talent development offered by the University. Constantly expected to do more with less. Few opportunities for professional growth beyond getting P & T.

job_title: Research Associate in University Park, Orange, FL
pros: Great atmosphere, flexibility and people. Lots of work and encouragement and smart students. Great atmosphere, flexibility and people. Lots of work and encouragement and smart students.
cons: Bad atmosphere, flexibility and people. Too much work and encouragement and too smart students. Great atmosphere, flexibility and people. Lots of work and encouragement and smart students.

review_title: Part Time and exactly what I needed at the time.
job_title: Food Service in State College, PA
pros: Hours were great, however the work was not demanding.  I spent alot of time hanging out with other employees on my free time.
cons: Management was out of touch.  they enjoy such a surplus of profits there is no reason to try and improve

review_title: It is a job that helps pay the bills.  Decent work environment and nice atmosphere, but not a career position.
job_title: in State College, PA
pros: It is a fun place to be with a lot of things to do, and interesting people to converse with and learn from in a university setting.
cons: The overall pay and work hours are less then desirable.

review_title: Most administrative staffs are not nice for postdocs
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in University Park, PA
pros: Penn State is really a big University, you almost could find any subjects here you may join in. The career development is also good if you are willing to be a faculty in the future.
cons: Most administrative staffs are not nice for international people, for example, office of international students and scholars, some department business offices

review_title: Review for the part time job
job_title: Part Time in State College, PA
pros: It is the part time job from university, and the manager is very nice. I liked the overall atmosphere in the university.
cons: Since it is only a part time job, the salary is only a little bit higher than the state minimum. Sometime it is very hard to get a good parking spot on campus.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: People are generally pretty friendly, faculty and staff included. Facilities are great and many things can be done on or near campus. Funding in STEM is quite high, even post-government shutdown and there are no shortages of assistantships for graduate students.
cons:
A lot of the laboratories for STEM type research are in basements or sub basements which, after a year or two, gets more than a bit depressing.

I miss the sun.

review_title: Reasonable pay and benefits for graduate researchers
job_title: Graduate Researcher/Lecturer in State College, PA
pros: Great healthcare, good colleagues, further your education at a highly-ranked institution
cons: Graduate students work long hours, the pay is not great but think of it and the worth of your future degree, STEM fields aren't always hiring as much as you would think, variable experiences depending on field and adviser

review_title: Generally a good place to work. Much workplace drama and politics.
job_title: Lecturer in State College, PA
pros: Work a few blocks from my house, excellent support services for staff, I feel as if I have decent job security for the foreseeable future.
cons: Relatively expensive town to live in ($3000 in school tax alone for current tax year), the political correctness of a modern university is maddening, as a fixed term faculty member, the salary is low for a 12 month appointment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in State College, PA
pros:
Love the people and the overall laid back style of the office 
75% tuition discount 
Opportunities for professional development 
Diverse working environment
Colleagues generally care about each other  
LOVE STATE COLLEGE... best town ever
cons:
Having to pay for everything... parking... even thou you work here
Low pay and sometimes overworked 
Not many opportunities to get a promotion without switching to different departments 
Lack of recognition

review_title: Great science but is too cut throat
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in University Park, PA
pros: Resources. Well-equipped centers and labs. Collaborations. Knowledgable and helpful staff. Good students. The University is always renovating something.
cons: You are often forced to work extra hard, overtime (as a grad student and a postdoc). School is very competitive even within the school.

job_title: Facilities Management in Walker, PA
pros: PSU is a stable work environment . Benefits are great. Continuing educational programs are available
cons: PSU is so politically correct that true innovation or even glacial improvement is impossible . Divisions like the Office of Physical Plant are inefficient oligarchies run by empire builders not concerned about the big picture

job_title: Campus Rec Supervisor in University Park, PA
pros: Best student job you could ever ask for. Flexible Hours, amazing coworkers, supervisors that trusted you and gave you more responsibilities as you asked for them, fun work atmosphere and subject matter. You get paid to oversee sports!
cons: If I had to really fish for a negative, it would be that for some of the seasons you can face some pretty miserable weather, but that should be expected for sports.

review_title: Penn State: Nice place for graduate school
job_title: Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: Quiet and safe college town, beautiful scenery, friendly neighborhood, relatively low living cost, good football team, relatively close to NYC and Philly
cons: Long and cold winter, apartment rent keeps increasing and many apartments are not tenant friendly, crowded in football weekends, in the middle of nowhere

job_title: Lab Consultant in State College, PA
pros: very relaxed job. you can do hw at the job. no one stops you. get paid for doing homework. If you dont want to do much and get paid
cons: there is less scope for growth. the wage is very low. Besides the Media commons shift, all the other shifts teach you nothing.

review_title: I have been a research assistant for two years at Penn State.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: The environment is nice and friendly, the professors are available almost all the time and ready to help. It gives access to many data resources.
cons: The salary is not so good, enough to live in State College, but not more. You have to work 12 hours a day to satisfy all the requirements and do all the homework they ask from you.

job_title: Lifeguard in State College, PA
pros: Semi-flexible workweek, I could get a lot of hours if I wanted.  The culture of the lifeguards was fun.
cons: The management was very anal about unimportant parts.  It seemed like they weren't interested enough in the motivation part of management and

job_title: Lecturer, Adjunct in University Park, PA
pros: The adjunct position I chose to take here has been terrific. I've had complete support from my department and been able to design my own syllabus and assessments. Being an R1, the scholarly resources are unlimited.
cons: Naturally, the pay is low and the culture here can often interfere with students' work- football/clubs and activities take precedence. Otherwise, no complaints.

job_title: Lab Consultant in University Park, PA
pros:
- flexible hours
- great pay
- friendly and family-like environment
- good communication with management
cons: - delegation of duties: sometimes it's unclear about who's supposed to be doing what

review_title: Exactly what you expect from a big state university
job_title: Assistant Professor in State College, PA
pros: Most of my colleagues are really supportive. It is a quiet place to work, and pretty good starting point for an academic career. Generous start-up package for an assistant professor.
cons: College and departmental policies are a bit rigid. There is a sense of old boy's club in the department I worked for. Very isolated if you don't have friends or family in the area.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: flexible hours, interesting work, independent work, given own project to lead, good work environment, some training, lots of help available, good stepping stone
cons: there is not a lot of direction given for projects, quick start to projects with little background information on the work required

job_title: Human Research Technologist V in Hershey, PA
pros: The health benefits really are fantastic, and the cost of living in the Hershey area is very reasonable.
cons: Pay is embarrassingly low, and being a state institution salaries are determined and fixed by people in HR who have no concept of what you do or your true value.  Lack of external competition by any companies or universities within 90 min. doesn't help.

job_title: in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The Penn State University has a very active research environment. I finished my PhD degree there and would like to stay transiently in order to get a job.
cons: Do not have that much stress and pressure in this university. Weekend is hard to find many entertainment and community is small

job_title: Assistant Student Manager in Altoona, PA
pros: Works around class schedule for the students, great management, good pay for students, and great environment
cons: Work can sometimes be slow and monotonous, not really that big of a negative, but there are no complaints that I have

job_title: Student Worker in University Park, PA
pros: Fairly easy work as long as you don't walk in with an attitude. I was promoted after 2 semesters to Chef's Assistant and received employee of the month without really doing a lot of hard work.
cons: Chefs in the kitchen are so catty and gossipy.

job_title: Staff Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: worked in various offices, most of which were hospitable.  vacation and sick time is good.  monday through friday, day light hours
cons: management is for management, some offices have very stressful environments.  if not thick- skinned, will have a hard time adjusting to clique environments.  when voicing concerns/grievances, will likely be targeted by management and bullied out of the office

job_title: Research Assistant in State College, PA
pros: Access to state of the art facilities and respected professors. An excellent summer opportunity for college students looking to get research experience.
cons: The pay is minimal, but to be expected because it is a research job for undergraduates. Other than that, no cons!

job_title: Warren Commons Cashier in State College, PA
pros: Pay was very good for just ringing people out for food. Management was very understandable with scheduling. The staff was very friendly. Co-workers were fun and easy to get along with.
cons: Most of the staff are college age, so college attitudes and drama come along with it sometimes.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in University Park, PA
pros: State of the art research facilities, Nice work environment, office and facility staffs are really nice and helpful
cons: Expensive place to live. Apartment rents are very high even though State College is not near any big city. Penn State can do better in terms of stipend.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Altoona, PA
pros: Friendly and supportive colleagues, tons of internal research support, wide discretion over courses taught and teaching style, frequent training and professional development opportunities, all the resources available to Penn State overall, free parking
cons: Some turnover in staffing, existing gender gap in pay, frequent budget cuts, event times sometimes hard to balance with family life

job_title: in State College, PA
pros: The benefits are very very good.  Living in area is nice.   Access to university events a big plus.
cons: Isolated in central pa.   Health insurance could be better. Raises typically very low.  Work not always interesting.  Lower salaries rhan "real world"

review_title: Dissapointed, not how great company is run
job_title: IT Specialist (Now Consultant) for Servive Desk in University Park, PA
pros: Ease of relaxed environment, opportunities to excel and advance, performance recognition, excellent compensation for entry level position, private offices (not cubicles that are shared), funding of  training and travel/hotel per each semester with minimal restrictions, relaxed schedule, not rigid with policies that are intended for general clerical Office staff seen in secretarial units. This is less restrictive than heard about in other units.
cons: High number of "managers" in a field that requires independent and responsible employees managing themselves. Also, management do not share in work load, have extreme amount of downtime, and offer absolutely no leadership for the unit employees. Have observed targeting of employees for dismissal with no basis which prevents any possibility of building trust. When you have to avoid interactions with management, moral in the workplace takes a hit. Not a professional work environment without traditional leaders. This makes the workplace void of any levels above mediocre. If you are accustomed to great feats and accomplishments in your work, this job will be difficult because those are somehow perceived as a sort of threat and not desired or allowed. Makes no sense, so cannot explain beyond this. Advice: if already living  in the area, good job to have but do not move here  for it. Job security does not exist at this company

job_title: Research Associate in State College, PA
pros: Good work schedule, excellent work ethics and state of the art technology. The research is top of the line and everyone is very helpful.
cons: Just the nature of the work, but some days there's a lot of work and other days it's slow. The work can get repetitive.

job_title: Grader in State College, PA
pros: State College is a very cheap place to live. The pay is good enough to have a compfortable lifestyle in State College.
cons: It become too monotonous if you are doing the same job. State college is a college town and does not have a city lifestyle.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Scranton, PA
pros: The faculty are helpful, the department heads pretty much give you the space you need to run your classroom your way.  Training is available if you'd like to take advantage.  It's a good environment with a strong student body.
cons: Parking, I guess.  Not really much to complain about here.  I guess if you need hand-holding, it's not the place for you.

review_title: It was a great place to work while still being able to concentrate on my school studies.
job_title: Rec Sports Supervisor in State College, PA
pros:
The flexible hours, especially being a student
Friendly co workers
Ability to advance higher up and take on leadership roles even as a student
cons:
Lack of accountability on fellow co workers
Open up more to technology and how it can better develop communication
Small budgets

job_title: Math Grader in Erie, PA
pros: Get to work on my own time and wherever I please, such as in the comfort of my room.
cons: You only get paid minimum wage and there is no room for promotions. Grading papers gets pretty repetitive and boring.

job_title: Lab Technician in Ithaca Coll, NY
pros: Amazing community, they have an excellent research program, and they are a large campus with a large research body in Entomology
cons: Parking is not required but costs between $10-$50 a month depending on distance from certain labs, also average wage is for starting techs is low.

review_title: Avoid the Physical Plant if you want to work at Penn State.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in State College, PA
pros: Flexibility, good work/life balance, decent benefits, a lot of opportunities for training and education, 75% off tuition. That's pretty much it.
cons: Let me start off by saying that I really enjoyed my job for about the first year or so. During that time, i dismissed some of the following information as no big deal, but the issues kept piling on top of one another, I couldn't help but lose any and all motivation to continue my high performance. If you don't value your employees and their contributions, they will find somewhere else that does! At the office of physical plant, not many people  care about making things better. Most are content doing things the way they've always been done. As long as kids want to go to Penn State, we get paid, so why bother putting in any extra effort? OPP says it values employees and wants to make things more efficient, but many decisions that are made go against best practice and efficiency. Incompetence gets rewarded, especially if you make friends in the right places. People take multiple hours for lunch, are on personal calls all day, and don't get their work finished yet they still get promoted. Working hard and exceeding expectations gets you nowhere and barely a thank you for your contribution. People will intentionally make you look bad if they don't like you, which has happened to to me as well as other coworkers. Some managers and directors only care about looking good to their superiors because their main concern is their own personal gain. If you don't follow the crowd and join the clique, you will be ostracized. I have asked mutiple people in leadership roles for various means of assistance in my career developmeny and I've gotten laughed at and scoffed at on multiple occasions. I have made suggestions and recommendations that were ignored but then implemented later as someone else's idea. I have received significant additional work and responsibilities but I was denied a pay increase and denied a job upgrade mutiple times. I was lied to on multiple occasions regarding my position by management and human resources. The office of physical plant at Penn state is the absolute worst cultural environment I have ever worked in. Do not work here if you are the kind of person that is an individual and not a follower who falls into the crowd. Do not work here if you like efficiency, fairness, accountability, respect, communication, and collaboration. If you are the kind of person that keeps your head down and follows the crowd, is very agreeable, and doesn't voice your concerns, you'll fit in with the clique and you'll be fine at the physical plant. If you're not one to ruffle feathers and you don't like making suggestions for improvement or pointing out flaws in a system or project, then OPP won't be all that bad for you. There are a ton of opportunities for advancement, but you'll only move up if you are able to successfully navigate the social and quasi-political network of ladders. Ability means very little in comparison to how much someone likes you or how they perceive you based on someone else's opinion. Furthermore, management will lie to employees or completely withhold information to avoid having to "deal with" people's reactions to change. Managers will completely ignore emails and will not respond, but will blame others for it. The lack of communication is disturbing and again, no one is held accountable.

cons: The organizational culture can be inflexible at times as the staff sometimes struggles with adapting to change and working alongside true innovative thinkers. They do have some initiatives in the pipeline that have the ability to be successful, with the right messaging and training.

review_title: Not quite ready for the new Millennium
